These skills that are taught are the FOUNDATIONS to becoming competent health-care provider and can easily distinguish the "good" providers from the excellent.

TLDR: Excellent program with phenomenal instructors who have high standards for their students. There's a lot of work but you'll learn a lot and become a better health-care provider because of it. On the fence? Try it out, you won't regret it.

review.author: Dee B.
review.description: Office staff is rude and hateful. No manners, and this is majority of the time. Toxic environment.

review.author: Alexander P.
review.description: This school is the best it has such great teachers and I am absolutely amazed by this school

review.author: Dread M.
review.description: I went to the middle school and it sucks, from teachers, student behavio, food, bathrooms. The teachers are "Ok" as most are only there to get money and leave and don't care, but there is a few that stand out, such as the librarians or the extra curricular teachers. Ive caught students having sex in the bathrooms with weed, vapes, cigarettes. The food is absolutely horrible as is they serve nacho cheese the cheese is a solid, and the bread is hard as a brick, the pizza horrible and its sauce is brown and not even close to red

review.author: Samirah S.
review.description: The middle school sucks. my daughter goes to this school and she has gotten jumped many times because she said that someone was death and mrs. Batts don't get me started she is extremely racist she told my daughter who is black that her race was the reason for the world's problems. Not only that but my daughter said she had gotten iss for going outside and she got iss because there was a code medical

review.author: Chuck K.
review.description: Maybe I'm biased because I have Columbia University so close by but I didn't find UPenn's campus all that impressive.  Finding parking was difficult and the campus just seemed so old.  I know it's an Ivy League school, but it wasn't that aesthetically pleasing.  Or maybe it's my anti-Philly bias.  I don't know.  I can safely say it's the least attractive campus from the Ivies that I've visited.

review.author: Clare D.
review.description: I attended Penn Engineering for my PhD from 1989 to 1991, then stopped to pursue life's passions, got a job at Penn, got engaged, married, had children, divorced, and still work here. I'm a "lifer." I'm currently going for my third master's degree at the Law School. The campus is a beautiful place. When I first arrived here in 1989, it was kind of seedy outside the campus in West Philly. Not going to lie, I was afraid to stay out past 8pm. Moving to Center City was probably the best idea. The resources of this university are vast, so whatever you want to study, you can probably find it here. I do wish I attended this school as an undergrad because it seems the people who love this school the most are undergrads, but I do not regret the path I took to get here. If I had to do it all over again, I'd probably stay in Boston and go to the big H.

review.author: Tiffany T.
review.description: I was in town for a conference and wanted to check out the famous UPenn campus. The campus is located a few miles outside of downtown Philly. Surrounding the campus are other schools as well. \n\nThe campus was beautiful in the fall. It is situated in the heart of a city, one moment you passing shake shake and minutes away you're on campus. The campus is pretty easy to navigate. A clean environment and very safe. Definitely seems like a great ivy league to attend!

review.author: Aelita P.
review.description:
I went to Penn as an undergraduate and work here currently, BUT I'm going to write this review from the perspective of a visitor. Physically, Penn is a beautiful space. It's been officially recognized as an arboretum for its cultivation of diverse plant species. 

It's not a large campus, but there are a lot of cool nooks to wander in. My favorite space is the "Bio Pond:" great for eating lunch, wandering, and/or watching turtles sunbathe. Locust walk is incredibly beautiful as well. In the summer you're walking under various shades of green and in the winter you can walk under glowing golden lights. 

If you're in the city I think Penn is well worth a walking tour.

review.author: Bella R.
review.description: Long overdue!\nI had the honor of taking a course with Professor  David bell and my experience has been unforgettable since. He's passionate about marketing and takes the time to thoroughly answer everyone's questions. He's patient and makes learning fun! Professor Bell taught one of the students (founder) of WarbyParker glassses and used their experience to teach about online marketing and the new digital world. \nAlso, had the honor to sit down with him for dinner with my GM and made me wish I had gone to apply for Grad school with UPENN!! My General Manager also loved taking his course and we both utilized some of his strategies to propose to our boss which was effective!

review.author: Marina G.
review.description:
Part 1. This was the worst experience with a university in my life. I have two undergraduate depress from exceptional school, one in a consortium with U Penn. Those two previous schools were excellent in the treatment of students, teaching, provided health services, advising, and on and on. U.Penn. fails students, at least graduate nursing students, horribly. Just look at the suicide rate. Also, this past year the new head of the mental health center killed himself after working here just 8 months I believe. He had come from Cornell, a notoriously depressing place. Penn is a dangerous cruel environment that you should avoid if you care about your sanity or education at all. 
I tried to contact my advisor when I started here. She didn't respond for over six months. I finally went to the general student adviser, but sadly she quit. The advisors I had, and there were multiple, were selfish, unhelpful, and generally failing their advisees. Penn does little to help the student or guide them. I had to jump through a large number of hoops for the graduate nursing program and Penn did nothing to make this easier for the students. There was no advisor guidance, paper instructions, nothing to help make it easier. 
We were required to provide health records, but Penn didn't accept mine for some reason even though my prior employer (a hospital) accepted and provided them. They wanted to re-vaccinate me for literally everything. 
Getting licensed in NJ and DE is not easy and Penn doesn't help you. 
They don't bring in someone to do flu shots for the nursing student or give step by step instructions on where to go to fulfill the licensing procedures. I found that the advisor really only cares about doing his or her own research, teaching is a distant second, and helping students comes last if at all. 
When I started there they said they wanted us to succeed and they would do everything they could to help us do that. That's a blatant lie. If you send an e-mail with multiple questions, I know from experience you will either get a response to only one of your questions or get turfed off to someone else to answer you.  If you need extra help in a class and ask the professor where to find someone to tutor you, they either don't know or send you to someone who is tutoring 15 other people at the same time and only shows up about 3 out of 8 sessions because he or she is busy too. 
Yelp is saying my review is too long, so I'll do another review as part two.

review.author: Angie L.
review.description: I had a very dreary forecast of UPenn coming in, but after spending just one minute on campus, I realized I was dearly mistaken. Academics aside, the campus is just gorgeous. Red bricks form the walkways, which are heavily shaded by rows of towering trees. The buildings are historic, but not old or run-down enough to the point of archaism. \n\nI attended an info session and campus tour, which were both fine in their own right (I got a bunch of free "fancy brochures", which I'm definitely not complaining about), but the campus itself made the biggest impression. The off-campus atmosphere was mediocre at best, but the on-campus environment proved itself to be homely and relaxing and just a wonderful place to spend an afternoon (or four years) at. Stop on by, I recommend it.

review.author: Joop V.
review.description:
I had a privilege to study at the University of Pennsylvania for my undergrad and loved it so much that I chose to go back there again for my graduate degree a few years after I finished my undergrad!

Aside from being in an urban area, what I particularly like about Penn are the interdisciplinary approach to teaching and a strong focus on exposure to international/cultural awareness. While I was there, I had a chance to take classes from business and engineering to urban studies and foreign languages (I even got to take American Sign Language class, too!).

My friends all are successful in the paths and passions they choose to pursue. The university does an excellent job providing theoretical knowledge but also equipping its students with practical sense on how to operate and apply what they learn to the real world!

review.author: Nancy H.
review.description:
I'm tempted to write about Penn from an academic and student culture perspective, since everyone here has plenty opinions about that. But since this is Yelp, I'm going to direct my attentions to people who are going to visit this place for the beauty of the campus, or who are thinking of living nearby, and not to try to impose my opinion on prospective students (who should be asking current students 1:1 for college-picking advice anyway). 

Penn's campus's big cohesive force is Locust Walk, which connects the high rise residences (where a lot of students end up living, either in the high-rises or on cheap off-campus housing) all the way to the buildings on the far sides of campus. This brick boulevard is lined with trees and keeps the campus from feeling like just another part of the city. Walking down Locust sort of feels like walking through an actual park, especially at night when the hordes of students have trickled down to just you and your footsteps. 

Penn's buildings are quite grand and beautiful, especially Fisher Fine Arts Library, which is so nice that drawing classes tend to come here to sketch its innards. The New College House, on the other hand, is very contemporary and decked out with cool tech for its residents. Finally, the high-rises offer views that you don't get tired of for your entire undergrad career, and only suck in the winter when they form wind tunnels of hell that blow you backwards while you struggle towards your dorm. 

Foodwise, the campus is ringed with tons of restaurants, but the best food is across the bridge near Rittenhouse Square. Same with groceries -- there are some expensive, meh-quality places to get ingredients on campus, but Trader Joe's has by far the fresher produce and fairer prices. 

Time sort of passes instantaneously while walking around campus after you get used to it, and I've learned to cut through certain buildings to shave off five minutes or so from my commute at a time. As a student the campus feels smaller and smaller every year, but the streets named after tree varieties never quite become engrained into memory, and in freshman year I remember getting lost between 38th and 39th.

review.author: Ivan R.
review.description: A top school in engineering and applied sciences, with top faculty and cutting-edge research.

review.author: Lauren K.
review.description: Forget the tour, Writ 089-302 Policing Social Media is an objectively wild attraction on campus.

review.author: Joyce J.
review.description: I will not rate the school according to its educational excellence. The whole world knows that Penn is one of the best universities.  I am just reviewing it based on my tourist experience ;) \n\nMy husband being an alumnus,  acted as my tour guide. I liked how there are lots of trees and plants around a campus in the middle of a city.  The buildings are beautiful and historic. The lay out of the campus seem convenient and fun for the students.

review.author: Dominik D.
review.description: Fairly beautiful campus. So much history can be absorbed just by walking around. It's spacious despite its urban setting.

review.author: Hank C.
review.description:
I really enjoyed living and going to classes (when I could wake up for them) here.

While there are the downsides (inevitably, cockroaches, dirty roommates in  the dorms, crazy people begging, and what a cost ... my wallet still hurts), there were plenty of plusses.

For the people who complain about Penn contributing nothing... consider that it's one of the largest employers in the region, contributing to countless people's income in that regard. The students and staff use millions of dollars worth of local supplies and spend plenty of money in the city proper, not just on-campus. While students are encouraged to be careful of the surroundings, it's no where near as dangerous to students as more than a dozen years ago.

While some of the buildings were old and scary (ever check out the basement in DRL?), others are brand-spanking new and spit-polished shiny (Huntsman, anyone?), and the University does try hard to make everything close enough for students to access for those who either don't wish to go downtown or don't know better to go downtown.  The food carts were a blessing at almost all hours, the cafeteria food wasn't really that bad (although the service was inconsistent), and Wawa was always open to serve up a sandwich for you. Over the years, more bike lanes appeared and more cops patrol the area, and a facelift was given to Houston Hall / Perelman Quad, the Quad itself got air conditioning, and the high rises were given new names (although I'll still refer to them all as High Rise East, North, and South), and new windows & paint.

1920 Commons still can't match Hill for food, but they added many fast food options on-campus from a Taco Bell to Subway. While I miss my Burger King, the food carts, again, help to make up for it.  Fresh Grocer now adds value as a large grocery store for the students at a decent price, and the Bridge provides entertainment as a movie theater.

New Deck, Smokes, Allegros and more are food options, and bubble tea has even grown from when my friends decided to do it as a project during their college years. And Locust Walk has even undergone renovation... they moved Ben Franklin to in front of Steiny-D for now as they repair his old spot by the compass.

A big university hospital helped to diagnose issues with friends, and treats countless community members for injuries both great and small.  Research is heavily invested in, and the libraries are second to none.

There are bad professors and good, but that's like any other institution. I can't name a single school which has outstanding researchers & outstanding teachers in every single class, nor will there ever be with the plethora of people that come through here. 

Need-based aid is now all grants, no loans, so that's amazing in and of itself. A huge amount spent on Hey Day, Spring Fling, Homecoming, and more for alumni and students.  Cheap dental work at the Dental School. New expensive housing for people who want to live close to the school, but still the old dorm grad housing for those who don't want to do that.  Museums (the ICA and University Art/Archeology), and displays, plenty of speakers coming through the Kelly Writer's House and Irvine, or small preceptorials that introduced us to wines, dinosaurs, or cuisine in Philadelphia. A restaurant school just minutes walk away.

Anyone remember Walnut Walk? Or Feb Club? Dances & parties, frat houses and off-campus housing.

I miss having everything so close. University City it may have been complete enough for the students to isolate them from the city, but it provided a very stable base to go wandering out to the rest of the city.

review.author: The Krazy Koala K.
review.description: Nice campus. Historical building, green trees, lawn for reading, if u venture out a bit to the tennis court cross bridge, you will find nice track and field and environment there. It's also good to jog along the river. Love the campus here.

review.author: Karen F.
review.description: I attended here in the mid nineties as a grad student at the School of Dental Medicine - and believe me, 3 stars is as generous as I can be.  I was harassed by a sadistic Bay Instructor, chased down Baltimore Avenue by "Hatchet Man" and generally had a miserable experience which may or may not have been the fault of the school.  Meanwhile, I got good grades - but transferred out to escape the scourge of West Philly at that time.  (It's alot nicer there now.)\n\nI have a feeling the undergraduate experience would have been better.

review.author: Phillip Y.
review.description:
CLASSES- UNDERGRAD/GRAD (4 out of 5)

I went here for undergrad in ChE and took a grad course in MSE.  Overall, classes here are pretty good.  Class sizes can be crazy huge for your standard chem, phys, econ, etc.  Competition is also pretty high so it can be daunting.  Profs here ranged from accessible to inaccessible.  At the time, Penn Course Guide was good to rate profs so you know what you are getting yourself into.  Now, I'm sure there are online reviews for classes.

LIBRARY- GENERAL COLLECTION, ILL, EZ-BORROW, PRINTING (5 out of 5)

I can't complain except for the price for borrower's access as alumni.  As a student, it's great but sucks to be an outsider like alumni.  Catalog is pretty huge here and if you can't get it here, librarians can get it for you.  Printing basically sucks now.  Before, I remembered as an undergrad printing everywhere was free with your tuition/fees.  Now, it's nickel and dime you by charging your Penn card like a copy card.  

GYM- REC CENTER, SWIMMING POOL, CLASSES (4 out of 5)

Wow, this place is HUGE.  Pottruck is much larger than I remembered when I was an undergrad.  However, the fees will bite you in the butt since it's optional for grad students.  The outdoors rec center is pretty decent with outdoors climbing clinics.  I found it to be pretty reasonably price and good experience.  Pool is really nice here as well.  Tons of cardio equipment here as well as class rooms for yoga/zumba/etc.

BURSAR'S OFFICE/BOOKSTORE (2 out of 5)

A bit of a nightmare for registration.  Alot of red tape from dept to Eng school to Registrar's Office.  It helps to have patience when registering a course outside your dept.  Overall, not the most pleasant experience and tuition here is pretty steep.  I soon realized after getting the bill- at least my company paid for it.  I had to study like hell for the course to do decent in the class- still it was a tough grad course.

CAREER SERVICES (5 out of 5)

I used career services in the past as an undergrad for on-campus interviews from neighboring companies.  However, I think I have benefited more now with their counselors and mock interviews.  The staff here is great and very accommodating.  There are counselors for each school- Eng, College, Dental, etc.  So, they specialize in all areas which I haven't found from other schools.  Easy to get help over the phone or onsite and help out alumni as well.  I can't say enough that this place is just a huge asset when it comes to career search/development.

VERDICT (4 out of 5)

I can't say that I loved being a student here.  It's stressful even taking a grad course.  However, education wise it is probably the most challenging in my mind.  I had some really great profs who saw my perserverance and kept me afloat when I felt it was unending battle ahead.

review.author: Marissa R.
review.description: Go Quakers. The FIRST UNIVERSITY in our nation - Thank you Ben Franklin!!! And the very first computers - ENIAC - were from Penn too!

review.author: Pamela A.
review.description:
Writing this from a first-year graduate student's perspective. The resources at Penn are amazing. Basically, if you want to do it, you most likely can at Penn. 
The faculty that I have interacted with have been amazing.
students in my cohort have done so many amazing things prior to grad school, which makes classes interesting and engaging. 
The libraries are beautiful. Students usually use the words Fisher and Hogwarts in the same sentence. I have found Fisher to be very quiet and a great place to study. Van Pelt has so many great spots to write papers and read at. Van Pelt also has a quiet graduate student area that you can swipe your Penn card to get into, as well as a new reading room (located just as you walk into the library - to the right), and beautiful views of the city.
The graduate student community here is also a definite plus! There are a lot of events offered to meet other graduate students. Plus there is a beautiful lounge to study in.
I could go on, but to sum this review up - my experience at Penn thus far has been amazing (I know---complete overuse of the word.)

review.author: Nick C.
review.description:
Wharton Finance grad here. Could we limit reviews to people who actually attended Penn? if you've never eaten at a restaurant, your opinion of the food isn't going to have much value.  

Anyway, Penn has a few attractive and historical old buildings, but you can see these with a quick campus tour. Other than that: 

-It's a poor value (very expensive, but State U. class sizes) 

-It has little practical point (what little you'll remember from all those courses a few years later you could have learned by reading a couple of books).

-It's in a dangerous part of town in a lame city with terrible weather. Your sidewalk will thaw out around May. 

-While there are some cool people, it's populated largely by prep school kids whose "parents" were often the older kids who picked on them. This cohort dominates the social scene. 

-It's too big and impersonal for anyone to really care about the lives of its undergrads. Penn is churning out industrial sized tanks of Bud Lite, not craft brewing quality in small batches. They could devote resources to actually mentoring and developing students, but then who's going to pay for all those new buildings? 

Sure, your degree will impress interviewers with Fresno State MBAs, but do you really want to work with dudes from Fresno State?

review.author: Bjorn H.
review.description: My girlfriend, daughter, and two friends went to Pinot's Palette Cherry Hill location on December 26, 2021. The artist did a great job directing us and the staff was friendly and supportive.  We all had a great time and will do this again!  Highly recommend

review.author: Brian S.
review.description: first off I'm very thankful they made it happen I called last minute on the day off & they did everything they could to accommodate us. We had Amazing time! our instructor was very fun lively & interactive. She made my girlfriends  birthday party one she won't forget!  We were walked thru how to do everything, she made time for us to enjoy each other while painting. it was an amazing time. they really worked with us to make it a time we won't forget. She definitely deserves more then what she's paid. They gave her a free painting for her birthday and a birthday card canvas. I love this place!!!

review.author: Carol E.
review.description: I had done the blacklight party and had so much fun doing it. Our instructor was great and our paintings came out awesome!!!! We painted in the blacklight for about 90% of the time and the music playlist was fun n upbeat. The place itself is new and has a great view of the stores in the plaza and even Philly. Pinot's has so many other options that other paint events & places at comparable prices. They even have a truck to take things mobile. If youre looking for a different kind of paint party where you'll be happy with the results and have a fantastic time, then this is the place to go to. Thank you to Rosa & Tre Thomas who have a beautiful establishment and ensured a great time!

review.author: Tabby W.
review.description: My friend and i went last night had a great time... i really enjoyed the instructor, she was fun and willing to help with the little details. I think the fact they have Ice and glasses made a nice touch.  I will definitely go back!

review.author: Kat M.
review.description: Attended recently with a large group of folks attending a wedding shower. Enjoyed it immensely and not just because of the people I was with. The individual who lead us on our way to becoming Van Goghs (apologies for forgetting her name) was really good at facilitating our very large group and keeping us all in sync. Highly recommend this activity/venue for any group looking for something a little different and a lot of fun!

review.author: Fred B.
review.description:
When looking for an adult game, family game or an educational gift this is the place to go. It's so nice to have a store like this in the neighborhood. Learn, Play Grow, their mission is to change the way people see education by making highly interactive and memorable learning experiences available in a quick and easy way. 

They have hundreds of games, puzzles and brain teasers. ExtraordinaryED has items for for adults and families of all ages.  If you are unsure of what awesome gift to buy when you visit, don't sweat it, they offer gift cards. It's a great option and let's that individual select the perfect item for themselves.

Parking is metered street parking. They are located a block away from the Collingswood PATCO station, and if you have a Patco card bring it in to receive a discount off your purchase.

review.author: Dennis S.
review.description: As someone who is not a parent, this is not a place that I would usually seek out. But I was lucky to have the opportunity to stumble upon PlayArts for my friends' daughter 1st birthday party yesterday. The building of PlayArts is interesting as it used to be a historical public bath but it's converted into a children's activity center. The entrance to PlayArts on Front Street was a bit confusing as I had to go to the back entrance on Lee Street. But the staff didn't really communicate it properly and I had to call my friends who were hosting the event for directions to the birthday party entrance. The back entrance for the event has multiple shoe cubbies where you can put your shoes in. Then I entered a spacious room which was where the birthday party was in with a very long picnic table and birthday decor. What was very notable for me was seeing staff interactions with the children and how kind, genuine, and engaged they were with the child attendees in the birthday party. PlayArts seems like a great spacious place to customize into any theme and definitely is a great place to host events for children! Thanks PlayArts :)

review.author: Selena H.
review.description:
What an amazing space!  I've been wanting to attend a drop in play session for a while, but when PlayArts held a special mini photo session in collaboration with a local photographer, and free play after the photos, I jumped on the deal!

While not part of the normal business operations, the mini photo session was amazing - in a private room in the back, plenty of time for my daughter to feel comfortable and get a number of amazing photos. 

Then we moved to the play space and let my toddler go wild! The space is truly safe and entertaining for crawling babies through older elementary aged kids, with areas only the older kids could access and plenty to keep the younger kids entertained. We spent a solid hour, my child had a ball, and she was exhausted and took a loooong nap afterwards. 

I'm so happy we have a space like this in Fishtown, and we look forward to more playtime!

They also are available to hold private parties, and it's definitely a space I'll consider as my child gets older and we have parties with other kids attending.

review.author: R. S.
review.description: This place is everything! Hosted a 6-year-old birthday party at the peak of omicron and it worked -- the space is large with good air filters and circulation so people felt comfortable coming. We had about a dozen, masked the whole time, and the kids ran around like crazy having the times of their lives.  We were afraid a party wouldn't be possible...PlayArts to the rescue!

review.author: Dominique R.
review.description: It's a cool building but there's no toys in there ... it's pretty boring use of space with not much to do.

review.author: Morris B.
review.description:
I heard about this place thru an old coworker and decided at was a great saturday to try it out with the baby. Parking was pretty easy. As soon as we walked in I couldn't help but notice how vibrant but not too overwhelmingly bright it was. The decor was modern and well thought out as far as spacing. 

There was plenty for kids to do and they even have a big beautiful birthday room. And lots of comfy seating for tired parents lol.
 The hours and price point are great too and THEY DON'T CHARGE PARENTS AN ENTRY FEE like some other places. (it's only 12 bucks for drop-in and your first time is free if you give 24-hour notice online.) 

I will definitely be bringing our child back here. They even have fitness and social groups for parents btw!

review.author: Laura A.
review.description:
Argh!! Yelp glitch deleted my review! In sum: gorgeous space, sustainable toys for collaborative and imaginary play, and an affordable drop in price. I can come with my son and do work or read in the upstairs section while keeping an eye on him while sipping my coffee- living the dream, am i right?

The nest needs to up their game majorly to compete with this place. 

Pro tip.. if you have an older kid like mine (he's 4), arrive around 11:30 on the weekends. The younger kids and nappers clear out then! Also, your first visit is free!

review.author: Catherine L.
review.description:
Super adorable little kid play mecca in you-blinked-and-Fishtown-changed-overnight.

The building is really cool, a former bath house (no, not that kind of bath house), and it has really cool bones (see what I did there?). With exposed brick and some new skylights, the inside is airy and bathed in light even on a rainy day. The interior is well conceived and has a very modern Scandinavian industrial esthetic with a couple thin bright neon metal trees perched in the main play space.

There are at least a dozen separate play spaces with duplos, train tracks, dress up, magna-tiles, fuzzy green 'grass' reading nook, little trikes, play kitchen, climbing castle and a two floor play house, along with a little crawling hideaway. The toys on the whole, seemed to be sourced part Etsy, part Ikea, part Melissa and Doug, along with tons of European imports like HAPE and Plan toys.

There's a classroom in the back for classes, parties and a variety of specific kiddo activities. There are entrances both at the front and back of the building and there is an observation elevated space dedicated for snacking, for working and most importantly, for coffee drinking. The snack/coffee area is on an honor system (which I love - yes, we are adults!), offers a variety of kid friendly snacks (not just junk, unless you consider pirate booty, junk? ha!) beverages, along with Perrier and coffee (did I mention, there was coffee?)  Yes, there is coffee. Thank god.

Unsurprisingly, the place is packed on weekends and especially on rainy days. As far as the age group it appeals to, my preschooler finds it lots of fun, although the majority of the population that I have observed in there is younger.  When the space is in fully over-run, staff could make efforts to better organize the space, and there should be perhaps labels as to what's where, or where things should go? (would that ruin the whole look?) The house and castle have some perilous stairs/ladders that require more parents oversight (helicoptering?) than I would like and I wish there was a tumbling section or a little climbing wall so we could really tire the kiddos out. Without a membership, you are out $12 per walk-in visit per kid. Much better play space than the underground Nest downtown.

review.author: Jonny R.
review.description: Loved the space, and so did the kids, ages two and five (but the whole party ranged from two to ten). We were there for a birthday party and the two hours flew by. The music circle with the big drum was great, and so is the play area. We aren't members, so I can't endorse a membership, necessarily, but we did think it was great for a party and we'll consider booking it in the future.

review.author: nic j.
review.description: Great toys and great space to the kids to play. \nWe have been to a lot of different play areas but playarts is by far the best I have seen. Usually this places are a madhouse but here is it a much more calm environment even when there is a lot of people around. Fosters community not chaos. \nGear music also.

review.author: Joe B.
review.description:
We do the playground circuit in Fishtown pretty often - Shissler, Fishtown Rec., Liberty Lands in Northern Liberties, Cione Playground, etc. On a colder day this past February, we decided we still need to get out and moving, so we visited PlayArts, and it was well worth the visit!

The old cliche about first impressions is true. And PlayArts nails it. From the moment you walk in, you're greeted in a nice, clean reception area by PlayArts personnel who explain to you the concept, the rules of play, and the pricing scale. We initially decided to visit just for the day, but midway through our visit, I decided to go with a monthly plan. The kids had that much fun.

Highlights include: tons of interactive toys, play areas for older toddlers as well as kids as young as a few months old, cool seating areas for parents, the snack/coffee/tea mezzanine area, the cash-free policy, etc.

This past summer, we held our son's birthday party here as well. And it was awesome. Both the kids and parents had a great time. I could base my 5-star review entirely on the party because it was that excellent of an experience: from booking, to communication with PA staff, to the execution the day-of. I have a feeling it won't be our last party there!

review.author: Laura M.
review.description: This is not a great playspace for anyone under the age of 3. There are a lot of climbing playspaces, and a lot of small toys for older toddlers and children. It is also a very loud space, and very expensive compared to other playspaces in the city.

review.author: P. D.
review.description: I love the fact that the parents can setup shop upstairs and observe from a birds eye view.  It's bright and beautiful.  But, this place is really better for older children since there are no physical barriers to separate the toys by ages. So with my toddler, there are toys that she can walk to that I consider choking hazards.  They warn you at check-in about this, but I still think that's something they could work on.

review.author: A A.
review.description: PlayArts changed my life! It's the absolute best addition to the neighborhood - super friendly staff, beautifully designed space, and most of all kiddos love it. If you're raising a kid in the city, you NEED to become a member, especially in the winter months.

review.author: Shani F.
review.description: PlayArts is a magical new addition to Philadelphia's array of offerings for children.  The teachers are extremely skilled and support the interests and abilities of kids of all ages and abilities.

review.author: Jessica O.
review.description: Let's just start by saying my 2 year old LOVES this place! We live in MT Airy/Germantown section of philly so it is a bit far for us, but well worth the trip! After coming here a few times I decided that we had to become members! I'm so glad I did. The first fridays are awesome and it's BYOB so you get to have a few drinks while watching your little run wild lol! Very clean, welcoming and relaxed environment. The staff are always friendly and welcoming to my family. Usually when we go we're there all day and when it's time to leave my son has a fit! So glad I found this place. No charge for parents which I think is awesome! And for former Chesnut hill Nest members (they recently closed down and I thought my world would end) this place is awesome. With winter quickly approaching and having a very rambunctious 2 year old little man this will be our new home and I am very happy about that! Thank you Play Arts! You da bomb!!

review.author: David S.
review.description: I had my daughter's 1st birthday party at PlayArts. We had about 60 people including kids and it was amazing. Everyone had a blast. Obviously the space is fantastic but the team was equally as wonderful.

review.author: J M.
review.description: PlayArts is amazing! My 2.5 year old loved the music class and it was very age appropriate. I also loved the parent engagement as well. The teachers were enthusiastic and the flow of the class felt perfect. I can't wait to take more classes!!

review.author: Tara J.
review.description: The play space is modern, very clean, and fun. We had a 1st birthday party here and everything was perfect from start to finish. They provided the decor, cups, plates, water, etc. It was nice not having to worry about all that. You can bring your own food and drinks and they will set it up/clean it up. Party room is huge. Staff is very nice and helpful. Memberships, daily rates, and party fees are all very reasonable. Can't say enough great things about this place!

review.author: Juliet A.
review.description: This review is about hosting a birthday party there. The good: play space is spacious and fun with good music; can do a private rental. The bad: for all the money we paid we expected a stress free party. Unfortunately, the two "helpers" that were there were not well trained. They were polite but did not know where to place food or how to host. Most of the food and drinks stayed downstairs even though most of the parents were upstairs. They kept asking me what to do even though i was busy trying to keep up with the birthday toddler while trying to speak with some of the guests at least. This included very common sense things like should we serve cake before or after pizza. They  spent most of their time talking to each other in the back instead of ensuring the party was running smoothly. The birthday girl did not have a central seat at the table and ended up with trash in the back ground of her photos. And the list goes on. So while the space is cool,hosting a party there is stressful as you provide all the food and do the hosting and only get very basic decorations (no themes) plus plates/cups with little help and no guidance. They even charge for ice despite the hundreds you'll spend. Hopefully they'll come up with better packages and trained staff in the future.

review.author: Charles M.
review.description:
My niece plays basketball for this University. I actually spent a lot of time here when I was in HS while my mom was working on her 4th degree from Rutgers. She didn't want to come alone at night so I would accompany her to her classes. 

My cousin went here from 99-2001 and many other family members. So I suppose we have a long standing relationship with this school and it is a great University with two campuses or more in NJ. I can't speak for thier athletics department because Rutgers football program gets beat by everyone and I've only gone to one female basketball game. But the education is one of the best in the state. 

This campus sits on the waterfront in Camden NJ, one of the roughest parts of south jersey, but they do an excellent job of keeping the campus clean and safe for students. I've never known any of my 7 family members that graduated from Rutgers to ever have issues.

review.author: Wayne W.
review.description: I have just moved onto the Rutgers Camden campus for graduate school.  So far I am very impressed with the organization that they have with Rutgers new Brunswick.   I had gone to Newark Rutgers and they had no collaboration with the other rutger's so when I needed something it was annoying.  Here it is not the case they work well with the other rutger's and it makes things a breeze.  I am living in the graduate dorms at 330 cooper and I have to say they are gorgeous they are four bedroom suites and 4 separate bedrooms with a large living area and two bathrooms to share.  I have not been to any classes yet but have met with a lot of my teachers and they all seem very professional down to earth but professional which is what you want from a professor.  I am very glad they accepted me to come here because I have only been here a day and am amazed at this place.  They make you feel like you are at home with the massive campus all the amenities and security like you wouldn't belive.  If you are looking to finish your degree or try and get another I would recommend this campus.  This is a subjective view as I go here.

review.author: Tyler R.
review.description: I graduated from Rutgers University - Camden.  I go back regularly to help with alumni functions and to provide support with the Honors College and admissions.  This is one of the best academic campuses in the state, and you will learn more here and have access to so many opportunities in the Metro Philly, NYC, and DC areas because of the partnerships and faculty involved. Going here was a great decision, but I wish the university would make some capital improvements to the physical buildings to keep up with other universities. \n\nRutgers-Camden will forever shine on the banks of the old Delaware!

review.author: Julia K.
review.description:
I've been a regular of this establishment since 2009. it is difficult to write about a place that supplies you with the best tools in the world - knowledge; however, I can write about the servants. first of all, don't let the location intimidate you. it is Camden, but the "beautified" part of it. Rutgers police is everywhere and unless you are completely careless you will be safe. for example, I wouldn't walk back to the parking lot at night, but rather take the Rutgers bus. 
some buildings are better than others. do not expect Princeton-U feel when you walk down the halls. generally the place is fairly neat and clean. 
the administration is on and off: accounting people are helpful and pleasant; general administrative offices are... not so much. 
now, for the quality of education. there are some incredibly talented professors that will make you love your college experience. some adjunct  instructors are okay at best, but generally I am very satisfied with the quality. 
the career services folks are knowledgeable and helpful. 
the cafeteria is actually very good and  reasonably prices. 
the library is a little bit of a mess, but that is only because it's been under construction for the past couple of  years.
there is life on campus, thanks to different events and trips, etc... 
generally, it is a good bang for your buck.

review.author: Mike C.
review.description: This school sucks, there's never anyone here and when they are here their always in the bathroom when I'm trying to poop. The gym sucks Rex activities are non existent. 12 people live in the dorms so don't bother. You really should just go to Rowan at this point

review.author: E S.
review.description:
I'll apologize ahead of time for my lengthy review; however, I feel it's necessary to provide in depth details of my negative experience with hopes it could possibly help another family considering using this company for their infant care needs. 

I'll start off by offering some general advice for any potential customer considering using  Virginia is for Doulas. First and foremost, I would most definitely consider getting a written description of what a doula can or cannot do. The scope of my needs stayed relatively constant over a period of a few months. Unfortunately, Tiffany (the owner) changed her mind several times as to what her doulas could or could not do and as a result, we had to look for help elsewhere at the last minute. As mentioned, this changed several times based on Tiffany changing her mind alone.  

Secondly, a written copy of their sick policy is a must. Decide on whether you want your infant/child exposed to a sick doula. In our particular case, our son is a preemie. We verbally requested that any sick doulas should stay home to avoid any issues for our son and his weakened immune system. Our doula was sick and our pediatrician recommended that she not return to work until 48 hours had passed after starting antibiotics. Tiffany still charged us for those particular days of our doula being sick. Even after, our doulas health continued to decline and she had to miss work for almost a week. Clearly it was a terrible idea for her to work due to her own sickness, let alone work around an infant with a weakened immune system to begin with. As a result, our entire family got sick that ended in multiple doctor visits and medications just from being exposed to our sick doula.  

Another clarification that is extremely important is what happens when your doula can't come into work. Not only limited to being sick but for any reason they can't make it to work. On multiple occasions my family was left in a predicament where fill-in support was not provided. There were several instances where we never even received a text, phone call or email from Tiffany or anyone for that matter about the status of finding a replacement. We had to sign up with a completely different agency that could provide back-up help for our family at the last minute.  

Aside from all the frustrations listed above, the lack of professionalism on Tiffany's part was the most unsettling of all. I'm a fairly open-minded person. I realize mistakes happen. No one is perfect. However, I wasn't expecting Tiffany's unprofessionalism with regards to my genuine concerns. I was caught off guard by her rudeness and condescending attitude as if I had no reason to be upset. In many responses from Tiffany directly, it was almost as if I was being blamed or at fault for how those given situations were handled and I was offended. Both my husband and I have 25+ years of consulting experience with a strong background in client management and customer service. Tiffany could benefit from improving the way she handles interpersonal communication with her long-term clients. While she was cordial and pleasant for the first few months, over time her attitude went from pleasant to disrespectful and ill-mannered in all forms of communication. Not something you'd expect from the owner of the company. Her behavior and way of handling certain situations caused me to want to cut ties with her on many occasions, but I remained a long-term client because of one particular doula named Summer. 

We adored Summer because of her compassion, her knowledge and her love for what she does and for all the babies she cares for. Had it not been for Summer, we wouldn't have remained clients for as long as we did. 

I'm hoping this review will help anyone who reads it and is considering going the route of hiring a doula and using this particular company. I'm simply being honest about my family's personal experience and I genuinely wouldn't want anyone else to be put in some of the situations we were or be spoken to in the manner that we did.

review.author: Crsl C.
review.description: If you're pregnant and in the market for a doula for your upcoming delivery, I highly recommend Virginia is for Doulas. Tiffany and her team are extremely knowledgable and were helpful and supportive during my entire pregnancy through the delivery and post partum. I researched and considered other doulas in the area, but booked them after my initial phone consult because Tiffany was so friendly and informed, I knew I'd be in good hands. I ended up having an emergency early induction and was so glad to have Tiffany as my doula providing pain relief and support during what could have been a scary delivery - thanks to her help, my baby was born smoothly and I recovered faster than I did with my first child.\n\nThe package we chose also included birth photography and follow up birth announcement photo shoot; other doulas try to double as birth photographer but I'm glad they provided a separate photographer so the doula can focus without having to multitask. My photos came out beautifully and I'm glad we'll always have them to remember this special time. My husband and I also attended the birth expo they hosted which was informative and full of freebies. If we have another baby, I will definitely book them again in the future! Thank you Tiffany!

review.author: erin k.
review.description: I delivered with VIFD in April and had an outstanding experience. Kara and Tiffany were my doula teammates, and I had the great fortune that both of them were able to attend the birth. I had been fairly apprehensive about being able to VBAC but with the support of my team I did it, with a 8 lb baby, no less. Having the kind of triumphant birth I did made for a much better transition to new motherhood than with my first (emergency c-section). Our family is complete but if I were pregnant again I would hire the VIFD team again in a heartbeat.

review.author: Erin K.
review.description: Tiffany and the whole team at Virginia is for doulas were wonderful to deal with.  They helped us with postpartum care for our newborn twins many nights a week when I only got a few weeks off work.  I highly suggest them, especially for parents of multiples.  I have NO IDEA what we would have done without them!  Professional, well-run business with compassionate staff we felt very comfortable having in our home.  The added bonus of lactation help if you run into issues.  They came highly recommend to us.

review.author: Sarah A.
review.description: I found Virginia is for Doulas after Googling, and wanting an unmedicated birth knew this was the way to go! Heather and Jessica provided great info during the pregnancy and we enjoyed getting to know them. Long store short, my water started leaking at 35 weeks and I was induced. Heather was on call and was there for most of my labor. I ended up with an epidural - had I known this up front we would never have hired a doula service but realize now how nice it was having Heather there. She was able to provide lots of information, but also was another friend in the room. The whole process with Virginia is for Doulas was amazing - I would highly recommend them to anyone!

review.author: Madison M.
review.description: i would make it a 0 but that is not possible so i gave a 1. anyways you get int ruble for things that you dot do? and for the making fun of the lgbtq+  that was not my friend group. and this school needs a attitude adjustment. and the teachers don't teach all they do is sit in the front of the class like you went to collage to teach like do it.

name: Home Service of Clarke County Parenting Education Center
Home Service Of Clarke County Parenting Education Center

review.author: Rick B.
review.description:
Convenient, capable, and friendly - this low-key gunsmith is a retired Army SGM; hats off to him for his service!  I was very happy to find him so nearby.  

Ken is helping me with my AR10, but I'll also use him for inexpensive FFL transfers in the future.  I enjoyed visiting with him, and my wife loved his cute little dog!!

Highly recommended.

review.author: Samantha N.
review.description: One of the best schools in the area. Consistently high test scores. Smaller class sizes and one on one help. Caring environment. Teachers and staff are great. My parents and I both graduated from Cotter and my kiddo is currently attending.

review.author: Tracy T.
review.description: This place is amazing. Small 'classes' with caretakers that love children and have been there for years. Leaving my daughter here is like leaving her with family. I cloth diapered, sent breast milk, and now organic milk, and homemade baby food for my daughter with no complaints from them. The low turnover rate allows my child to feel comfortable going there and I can work without feeling worried or guilty. Days that I've had to go to work early they adjust their schedule and took her earlier (as early as 5:30 a.m.).\n\nI would change nothing about this childcare center. Someone could offer me free childcare elsewhere and I would not take it. I've tried every daycare in town, licensed in-home providers and babysitters. None compare to Bright Start. There aren't enough stars to rate how I feel about them!

review.author: David S.
review.description: Ugh...that first review on the haunted house was horrendous. It was so painful to read. The grammar and spelling made it feel like my brain was walking across a field of sharpened Lego pieces. I mean, there's a spell checker on Yelp and most computers/phones that you would write a review on have spelling and grammar checks that would literally take less than a minute to complete. Anyway, the college here is best described as cows grazing in a field. They're eating and moving around but not really doing anything or going anywhere. There's a few professors here who are diamonds in the rough but most should have spent their education careers at a daycare thanks to their insatiable egos and apathy. I went here for my basics to stay close to friends and family but eventually got tired of the lazy administrative staff that could care less about whether you enroll or get benefits and moved on to a standard four-year for my BA. I actually had to pay for one of my semesters out of pocket because they incorrectly submitted my VA benefits in spite of me working with them. After speaking to several classmates over the year and change I was there, I came to realize that my experience was a pretty regular occurrence with many, not just vets. Never in my entire life have I seen employees who care so little about their job or their clients and will do anything to get out of doing work. Sure, you're greeted with a smile, a handshake, and some wonderful sounding promises, but behind all that shallow fluff, you're being dismissed in the minds of the faculty and staff.

review.author: amy t.
review.description: HAUNTED HOUSE  This is not for the college per say..My husband me and my children went here last night for their Kids Bash.. Although I know several of the people that attend this university, You were unable to see their faces because it was so dark, they had masks on and were painted up. We had to take a hayride into the "woods" (the haunted house was on campus) Then you had to get off and walk across the broken down bridge. Finally you get to the house, its all black and all you can see is flashing lights. Our tour guide told us to stay close and dont get lost. When we first walked in it was a guy just lying on a couch with a knife in hes chest. Pretty funny if you ask me, he was trying to be slick and scare everyone by waking up. You couldnt see where the hell you were going so I have no idea who or what was in front of me and suddenly SMACK a freaking doll hit me on the head. They had dolls hanging by there necks suspended from the ceiling. The next room that was lit up was of a women vampire, she didnt do anything but smile, so she sucked!! We went on this damn bus, I didnt even know we were on a bus till our tour guide yelled "watch your step were getting off the bus now". What I was freakin out when the hell did I get on this bus???Next we went across another bridge and of course people were grabbing your legs, which was pretty funny because im so ticklish. But we get off the bridge and were in what looks to be a Forest, trees everywhere I lost my husband somewhere in the damn forest so im freaking out, IM LOST!! Suddenly all you could hear is roaring chainsaws all around me and Star,(my oldest daughter) as she had stayed with me.  They started chasing us, my daughter started screaming so I had to hold her all 40 pounds of her and make my way through this forest. Whomever it was they thought it was pretty funny and started poking me and her with the damn prop. Im not going to lie I was scared shit less. I should have gotten high before going in there!! Finally after running to catch up with my husband I fucking pushed him so hard into the damn wall, now that was funny!!!! I couldnt tell you what was after the forest because I just closed my eyes and hoped it would be coming to the end very soon. We finally got out of the house, and making our way back to the old ass bridge to cross that and go back on the hay ride one of the guys with the chainsaw started chasing me and Star again. He/She didnt go after my husband nor the others. My husband was rolling with laughter. So im wondering if it was someone we knew. He wont tell me. But it was pretty fun.. Worth the trip down there to see!

review.author: J M.
review.description: 10/10 would recommend taking Physics in this class. I didn't understand physics much while joking this class, but Mr. Bertram is a pretty awesome teacher. He explains everything very well. He refuses to let students fail. He will continue to help you until you reach your potential. He's also a really great person to talk to if you are needing academic advice or just an adult to share your feelings with if you don't have anybody to talk to. He's the best teacher I could've asked for when going to the Cabot schools. \n\nThe location on the map might make directions to the best class in Cabot a bit hard to find. Just stop into the main office and ask for directions to the best teacher ever and they'll point you the right way.

review.author: Janet W.
review.description: Loved it lots of will remember the Sun scene next time but it was a lot of fun lots of life guards so you know your kids are safe while swimming

review.author: Janina M.
review.description:
Nice new facility that opened up earlier this year, I believe just in time for the weather to warm up. Prices are extreme for under 42", at $7 and above 42" is $8. WTH? Only $1 for kids?  Would be better if there was another tier or a bigger gap between the two prices. Infants to 1yo are free. They offer military discount, so be sure to show your ID when you pay ($1 off admission).

There is a kiddie area, red slide that is todder friendly, diving board and two bigger slides (must be over 42"), and a lazy river. 

Plenty of seating around the pools.

Break times are listed so you know when they will be telling everyone to get out for a rest break.

Snack bar prices are a bit high, but straight forward, highest is $4, cheapest is $1. They have an off brand Dippin Dots, Icee, nachos, hot dog, chips, etc.

review.author: Jayda K.
review.description: Over priced and filthy. management was rude. Pool was dirty there are other places to spend money for swimming

name: Cabot Foundation for Arts and Culture

review.author: Amy S.
review.description: Not a clean environment for the children, there are mice in the building. The owner Vicki knows this, and still has not reported the issue. I know this firsthand, also the "teachers" love to take a nap with the children. I'm sorry, but when is it ever ok to nap when the kids are? Who is responsible when they get up and there is not an adult to watch them? I would not recommend the school to anyone.

review.author: Stacy D.
review.description: Not very equipped or trained to do African American hair. Even just plain hair braiding and ponytails are messy. Need more culture at this facility.

review.author: Nikki T.
review.description: Nice building, nice people.  Both my sons attend AHS.  The Teachers are responsive and helpful.  The JROTC program is amazing, very active in the community.

review.author: Dustin L.
review.description: I normally don't leave reviews unless it's something exceptional. In this case, it is exceptionally bad. This is the third college I've been to and by far the worst. The biggest reason I am leaving such an awful review is the fact that the financial aid office has refused to process my fafsa unless my parents commit tax fraud. They were separate at the time but the school wants them to refile as married not separate. I also owe the school a bit of money since scholarships didn't cover enough and fafsa wasn't processed so I had to solely rely on that. So I got a loan but I was told it wouldn't be active until the first day of classes. That means yet again my attempt to relieve the hold and register for classes was a bust. Next up is the food, the cafeteria seems to constantly under cook food. More specifically the chicken is almost always raw. And third is the teachers, but most specifically an english teacher named Mrs. Carter. Who gave me numerous zeros for assignments I turned in without any explanation why causing me to go from a B to an F in the last few weeks of classes. All in all I do not recommend attending this university.

review.author: Susan S.
review.description: Great staff dedicated to district support and student success!

name: Kumon Math and Reading Center of Fayetteville

review.author: Bill U.
review.description: Love the university and how it is embraced by the community. My son loves the town and school as well. Looking forward to visiting several times over the next few years.

review.author: Loosey B.
review.description: Great bookstore on campus to get some Razorback gear. Football stadium was under construction but the campus is nice to walk around.

review.author: Megan R.
review.description:
Sarah was an absolute asset to my birth experience. This pregnancy was as a surrogate, which required me to give birth in a hospital, so I knew I needed a coach and an advocate. My first and only other birth of my daughter, was attended by 2 midwives at home and was the best day of my life. So, I hired Sarah and Charli for their doula services and was comfortable with either attending, just happy I knew them and they understood me and my birth plan. 

Sarah showed up at our house right when the contractions kicked in. She guided me through them and made the call when it was time to walk to Providence Hospital. Along with my husband riding our cargo bucket bike and 9-year old daughter walking with me, we walked the 1/2 mile to the hospital, stopping every minute or two for me to lean against her and have a contraction. She provided me with shelter and guidance. When we got to the hospital, I was taken up to the birth center and learned I was 5 cm dilated and felt a sense of accomplishment. The final 5 occurred over 3 hours between the tub and the yoga ball in the bathroom. Sarah was my crutch during the hardest ones. My family doctor, who knew my birth plan well, showed up and they, along with the nurses, worked together to let me know it was time to get on the bed and push.

I squatted in reverse on the bed, holding tight to the railings. With every push, I could feel baby Penelope make her way through the birth canal, with intense pressure. I asked Sarah to guide me through the ring of fire so I wouldn't tear. We took it slow, allowing the head to crown, stop, head halfway out and back in, stop, head out, stop, shoulder out, stop, arm out, stop and then her body fell gracefully to the bed between my legs. I scooped her up, the nurses helped me untangle from the cord so I could turn around and sit with her. They toweled Penelope off, I scooted over and her new mama came over crying and sat next to me and I got to hand over the most beautiful thing in the world to the person who had wanted her most. I looked up at the room and everyone was smiling and taking in the moment, including Sarah. This was the most magical day of my life.

I can't recommend her and Charli enough. Having a doula or midwife is a serious luxury in giving birth and I also attribute my fast recovery (casually walking and biking within a week) to them. I needed no epidural, emergency treatments or stitches.

review.author: Emelia W.
review.description:
If you are on the fence about home or hospital birth, go with home birth! And go with this rockstar goddess duo of Hearth and Home to lead you through. It is one of the best life decisions I have made. Ladies, we have been designed for this, and we have successfully been having babies at home for thousands of years. Every woman who isn't high risk should give serious thought to birthing at home. Give yourself the credit that your body and mind are equipped for home birth. 

I have two beautiful children and two completely different birth experiences. My first son was born in the hospital, to make the long story short, I ended up being talked into an epidural and experienced a very chaotic 36hour long labor. Fast forward 9 years later, I wanted a different experience. I chose Sarah and Charlie, and I am so incredibly thankful I did. This time my birth was at home, in comfort and tranquility, with my partner and these two incredibly knowledgable ladies. I felt safe, I trusted their guidance. My son was born within 6 hours and by midnight Sarah and Charlie tucked us into our bed safe and sound with our son.

I really value how these two handled every step of my pregnancy. Tho I was low risk, I did end up with gestational diabetes. We were able to figure out how to control my blood sugar with diet, while I would have been told to go on insulin, had I followed through with Kaisers recommendations, a drastic measure for something that ultimately was controlled with diet. I always felt they made time for me, and were very attentive the entire pregnancy. I felt like we were their only clients! 

I also love them as a team, their personalities work great together and really makes the environment one of "we are all in this together" . That being said, when it came down to the birth itself, Sarah and Charlie had this great way of being there, but not being there. They always stepped in right when I needed that female guidance, but let my boyfriend and I share the experience together as well. That is how I wanted it, I loved that they made a plan with us ahead of time. The exact opposite I had in my hospital birth experience. 

After my birth in the hospital, with doctors I had never seen, bright lights, medication and stress, I felt defeated and down on myself for how powerless I was in the whole experience. My birth with Sarah an Charlie at home by my side was the most polar opposite experience. I was empowered, energized, calm and in control. I have never felt more like a real woman warrior than I did in that experience. These two supported and challenged me, guided and let me lead. We are forever changed by and grateful for Charlie and Sarah. We whole heartedly recommend Hearth and Home. They are the real deal, total B.A's of birthing!

review.author: Jaime T.
review.description: These women are literal angels in caring for pregnant and post-partum families. We decided to enter under their care for our first child after having been with Providence Women's Clinic for our first half of pregnancy. We were immediately relieved and energized by their loving and professional approach to patient care. They were not only easily accessible every step of the way, they created an environment that truly amplified the needs and desires of the pregnant family. I can't imagine going back to any other kind of care for future pregnancies and births. Charli & Sarah engage in deeply meaningful and skillful ways for any curve or bump in the road that can come along (and they always do!). I can't say enough about how wonderful they are and I hope you have the blessing of working with them like we did.

review.author: Joy A.
review.description: Charli and Sarah are pure gold! I birthed my 2nd and 3rd babies with them. My experience and treatment from interview to my final postpartum visit was so thoughtful, personalized and intimate that when I found out I was pregnant again they were my first call. I told them at my first appointment "I want to do everything the same!". Ultimately I named my 3rd daughter after them! (No joke, her name is Charli Jean; Jean is Sarah's middle name). I felt completely supported, and never judged. I couldn't even tell you what their opinion is on most topics because they don't push their agenda. They state facts and evidence and then tell you ultimately you know your body and should make decisions best for you. If you are looking for a home-birth midwife please, please, PLEASE go and at least talk to these ladies! You won't regret it

review.author: Awna T.
review.description: These two women are rare gems. I recommend Charli and Sarah to everyone I know. They help make to the whole adventure of pregnancy a sacred  time and experience. I have never felt more comfortable and safe at any health appointments in my life. I look forward to each appointment as they look at the mother and baby as a unit, and they make time to address any concerns or questions from the mother. I never feel rushed, always feel respected, never feel like a decision is being made for me, and I always feel heard. \n\nEven if you aren't using their midwifery services, I HIGHLY recommend their birthing class. My husband and I were thrilled with the entire experience. We both agreed that this class was well-structured and provided us an increased sense of peace and excitement around pregnancy, labor, and post-partum. We both feel like they touched on so many things that we hadn't learned about in the books, documentaries and articles we have been diving into on our own. I appreciate the in-depth look they provided on what is to be expected in each stage of labor. The entire class was structured perfectly and allowed for questions and conversation. I 100% recommend this birthing class and 100% recommend Hearth and Home for Midwifery as well.

review.author: Brooke A.
review.description: Living in an extremely rural location very far from a hospital, I thought that my hope for a home birth was out of the question. Hearth and Home Midwifery made our home birth a possibility while being cautious, preventative, and thoughtful about our distance from a hospital. I'm so grateful that I was able to have the birth experience that I wanted. \n\nMy family's experience with Sarah and Charli as our midwives was better than I could have imagined. They are two of the most caring, kind, supportive, professional, and knowledgeable people I have had the pleasure of knowing. They believe strongly in informed choice and made me feel that I knew best for myself and my family. I enjoyed my pregnancy journey with them more than I knew was possible from a medical provider and I can't wait to work with them again in years to come.

review.author: Jade C.
review.description: Something greater was truly at work during my prenatal journey and Charli and Sarah are proof of that.  Their pairing culminates the perfect synchronicity of strength, empathy and love.  I was able to let go, and just be, having the full confidence in the hands and hearts that held space for me through my birthing journey.  I was heard, I was encouraged and I was challenged when I needed a push.  I have never experienced such a personally transforming experience in my life.  Their dedication and love for what they do is evident.  I came out of that experience feeling like the powerful woman I had hoped to be and with the utmost respect and reverence for the gift these women give so freely and joyfully.

review.author: Lauren J.
review.description: Sarah and Charli provided incredible, compassionate care throughout my pregnancy and postpartum. Their support, kindness, and guidance helped me to enjoy my pregnancy, birth, and postpartum season. I left their care feeling empowered, informed, healthy, strong, and happy. Sarah and Charli are extraordinary health care providers and I will be forever grateful to have had the opportunity to be under their care.

review.author: Sarah E.
review.description:
I can't say enough about Sarah and Charli.  They are amazing!  My husband and I had been through two births before--our older daughter was born in a hospital, our younger daughter at home.  When I found out I was pregnant with baby #3, I knew I wanted another home birth.  I was so thrilled to find Sarah and Charli--a midwife team here in Hood River (vice Portland, which is where we traveled for baby #2 prenatal appointments).  
Sarah and Charli are such a great team--they were supportive and knowledgeable throughout my entire pregnancy (to include helping identify supplements to help relieve a nagging cough I developed during the third trimester and providing a sounding board when I got worried about baby's movements slowing down, which turned out to be what I expect was a big growth spurt!)  I had a history of going pretty long with my pregnancies--daughter #1 was born 14 days after her due date and daughter #2 was 16 days after her due date--but even as I passed the 40 and 41 week marks with my son, I never felt any sort of pressure to "get things going".  They really seem to embrace the fact that babies will come when they are ready and that it is a natural process that will just happen when the time is right.
When I finally did go into labor (I think I was actually in labor at an appointment with them, but pretty much in denial about it since it wasn't very intense yet and only 9 days past my due date), they were supportive and responsive.  When they arrived at our house, they seemed to have an efficient system for getting everything set up.  They were present when we needed them but gave my husband and me space to get into our groove as he coached me through contractions.  When it came time to push (definitely my least favorite part of labor), they gave encouragement and guidance, and I think I also may have squeezed the blood out of the hand they gave me to hold (sorry, Charli!)  After experiencing a significant tear with baby #2, I was worried about the same thing happening again.  But Sarah and Charli helped me breathe baby out this time--what an empowering experience!  And I didn't need any stitches! 
Sarah and Charli were so awesome, and I really recommend a home birth.  After my daughter was born in the hospital, I was so completely exhausted, but I wanted so much to hold and snuggle her that I ended up trying to stay awake so I could do so (hospital rules--no sleeping with baby).  Having a baby at home means you can eat whatever you want during labor, rest/sleep with baby, drink a beer and eat pizza after baby arrives (heck yes I did!) and just feel like you own your experience.  It has taken me far too long to write this review, mostly because life with three kids is just total chaos.  But it is with absolute enthusiasm that I recommend Hearth and Home--these ladies are the best!

review.author: Jessie J.
review.description: Anything is possible when you believe in yourself and are supported in that belief. I have always known that I wanted to be a Mama and have a big family, that I had so much love and life to share with the universe. I was diagnosed with Von Willebrands at 6 years old, I was told to forget about having children. Having a full blown bleeding disorder hindered me and created big fear. No sports, playing at recess, internal bleeding, transfusions and for many years the idea of experiencing a pregnancy and birth of my own. When I turned 17 my Dr told me that, with new medical knowledge, I could have a successful birth in an extremely controlled environment. No alternative laboring and birthing positions, in bed, the no's and blood disorder caused me to have a postpartum hemorrhage with my first birth. The fear and anxiety we had around birth was so unnatural, so clinical, so stressful. It Made all the kicks and magic riddled with fear. My next two births in hospitals were much better. I had amazing doulas and wonderful doctors and so much more knowledge about motherhood, birth and my body. Von Willebrands taught me how to advocate for myself and my health. I have always been fairly "granola" and I dreamt of birthing at home. I knew I was capable, My husband knew I could do it, but not many physicians did. Medicine is so much about fear and control these days, there is little self advocacy, and there just isn't enough support for women's health. After I was served so many "no's" when it came to my choice in birth, with the love and support of sisters near and far, after tears, and so much determination, I met the amazing Charli and Sarah. They heard me, they saw me, and they believed in me. They saw my strength, my ability, my knowledge of self. They listened to me through tears, smiles, blood, love and birth. They hugged my children close. They encouraged both My husband and I through birth and new life. With laughter, quiet, and care they left their magical imprint on all of our hearts. I couldn't be more honored to have them both by our sides as we welcomed Our fifth baby home. With full hearts and gratitude we recommend Hearth and Home.

name: St. John the Baptist Catholic Montessori School
Kumon Math and Reading Center of Excelsior - Minnetonka West

review.author: Joanne C.
review.description: College Nannies & Tutors Excelsior has a warm, cheery atmosphere, light and bright.  You notice this upon entering the door.  I have loved my tutoring experience--tailoring lesson plans to each student's individual needs, finding out what teaching style works best for them, and, most importantly, seeing their achievements. I love working there.

review.author: M S.
review.description: My children have been happily attending Minnetonka Montessori for a total of 4 years now, the oldest having moved onto elementary school.  They love/ed going to school there.  It is a warm and nurturing environment, as the teacher really gets to know the strengths and interests of each student and guides them in their exploration of many topics.  They learn how to interact with peers and direct their own learning.  Your child is not held back by the rest of the class if they are ready to advance further on a topic, such as geography, reading, mathematics, etc. . . Nor is a student left floundering or excluded if they are not ready to learn something.  The instruction is truly personalized to the individual student.  There is also a wonderful music class each week.  A real sense of community.  It is not a daycare or play-school.

review.author: Charles F.
review.description: The MAST course layout was awesome and a great value compared with other available options. Easy-to-read slides with lots of helpful information - all really well-designed and with great graphics. The quizzes definitely reinforced the slides. Big thanks to Craft Serving for putting this together!

review.author: Amy D.
review.description: The course is really well designed and easy to follow. They do a good job of setting students up to pass the quiz, focusing clearly on the most important aspects of the course. But I was disturbed by the background image in the Intervention Techniques portion where we focus for that entire segment on an image of a man pointing a gun at a scantily dressed woman (her naked legs stretched before him- to be real). Did NOBODY filming this vignette notice this "art?" Better check yourselves on misogyny Craft Serving and OLCC.

name: West Virginia University Co-Op Extension Service

review.author: Ashley L.
review.description:
Ah, Hollins oh Hollins :).
 I am at the undergraduate university as a senior, and have spent the past years building my resume through their connections with internships, and trying to find my way with a liberal arts education.
