The class is really geared towards anyone, at any level of talent or training. The instructor was amazing and did a great job of patiently teaching us the details of each step. 

They also provide you with cups and wine openers, so all you need to bring is your drink of choice. 

This is the perfect date night idea, whether you're married or searching for a first-date idea to sweep her off her feet.

We will definitely be returning!

review.author: Sara K.
review.description: Well, i have been to paint along nashville and to compare that to sips and stroke was eh. The woman went too fast and she kind of seemed annoyed when you were following quick enough. I mean, it's supposed to be a fun, wine-drinking type of relaxing fun thing to do and she made it a chore. On top of that she also didn't give us a lot of tips. It also didn't turn out like the internet version of the painting. I wont be coming back to this place. sorry.

review.author: Zoraida K.
review.description: This was my first visit and I went with some friends. I like the take home result and will hang it not at home, but in my office. The expensive art work stays home.  Anyway, I found the pace very slow and off putting. I know you have to let certain things dry before proceeding but does "watching paint dry" ring any bells. \nI would try it again, based on company and painting but not sure that they whole thing is for fast moving types like myself.\nThe people I went with LOVED it, so I guess it may just not be my cup of tea.

review.author: Toni H.
review.description: Very poor customer service and non-responsive.  I reached out to the Nashville location earlier this week to set up a small group event for today.  I reached out to the company via phone, email and text over the last 2 days stright on at least 5 separate occasions and they didn't respond at all until about 40 min ago to tell me the class sold out.  I haven't experienced such poor customer service like thus in years.  I would not recommend the company at all and will be taking my other personal and business outings to a different establishment.

review.author: Kathryn T.
review.description: There isn't a better place to paint in Nashville. They have the best instructors and they best monthly calendars. It is a place that both guys and girls enjoy. The teachers all go above and beyond to help you and teach you the painting. I would go every night if my apartment had enough wall space for all my paintings!

review.author: Samantha C.
review.description: This is SUCH a fun activity if you're in town with good friends.  You can look on their calendar to see a photo of the painting you'll try to mimic so you can decide whether it's in the realm of possibility of completing.  The instructor did as best as she could to compensate for my incredible lack of skill and gave me specific suggestions to make my painting not look like dirt.  The best part of the experience is the wine.  They have waitresses that make sure your "needs" are tended to and your cup is always full.

review.author: Jenna W.
review.description: My husband and I were visiting Nashville for our 5 year anniversary! I found this place online & immediately thought this might be something fun for us! The only class that wasn't full was a Sunday afternoon class & to my surprise the theme was graffiti hearts! \n(Perfect for our anniversary) There was one other guy in the class (to my husbands delight)! I felt the instructor went a bit fast, but this may just be what is required to get the painting done in the allotted time. But, she was very helpful if had any questions along the way! You just can't really be a perfectionist in this class. You more just have to go with the flow. \nOverall, we had a great time & have a wonderful memory & two art piece souvenirs that we plan to hang side by side in our home office! I might add the Sunday afternoon class was fun so I can only image what the Friday or Sat night class with a few drinks might be! I would like to add I do not think you would enjoy this class if you didn't have some interest in art.

review.author: Gianna B.
review.description: I would suggest going on the weekend with friends since its typically more lively, and for more of a romantic time, go on a week day! We really had a great time. Its bring your own alcohol, so when my husband and I went with friends, we just brought a boat box and had a grand ole time! PERFECT for a first date, or just a great night out doing something other than the movies! :)

review.author: Anna J.
review.description:
what a great idea, drinking and painting! Had a great time here last time painting away... and drinking away... haha

they provide you with everything, brushes, paint, canvas, tutorial...

but you bring your own booze, and they provide cups!  

Great experience, i love painting, so relaxing!

review.author: Hikeem C.
review.description: Seeing that I love art and the "occasional" drink, this place was right up my alley. The staff were friendly and very helpful to the ones who needed it. The room was filled with laughter and chit chat as everyone worked on their own unique piece. Although they start you off with a pencil sketch template on the canvas, you are allowed to customize the portrait as you see fit. The only negative thing that I can say about this place was that we didn't start on time and were rushed to get out. Other than that I enjoyed myself thoroughly and would love to do it again!!!

review.author: Bridgette C.
review.description: I've been going to Paint Along for years, and had yet to try this studio.  Considering its prime location in the Gulch close to me, I decided to give it a shot with some friends.  They definitely encourage a little more originality here...after painting your basic painting (selected from their calendar online) they give you other paints and even glitter (I know, I know) to play with.  Much like other classes I have attended, you can bring wine to enjoy as you paint.  They even have some paintings for sale as well.  The space in here is HUGE, and makes a great place for a group to go.  The pricing is reasonable ($30-$35 typically, with some specials for $20).  This studio, much like others, is a great place for people of all different levels of talent.  They do a good job with instruction and guidance.  I really enjoyed the location and the potential art pieces and will be back.

review.author: Laini B.
review.description: i went to SNS last night for the first time and I had a ball.  I attend with a Woman's organization and it was a pretty large group.  Our instructor was great and helped everyone achieve the goal of painting something they would be proud to hang in their home.  I will be back again soon to soothe my inner creative artist!

review.author: Lauren S.
review.description: I had a great time at Sips N Strokes.  I went on "Paint Your Pet" night, where we submitted pictures of our pets and the staff sketched an outline on the canvas for us to paint.  It was such a cute concept, and they gave us just enough direction to be helpful without micromanaging.  The staff were also very helpful, fun, and eager to show you a good technique and help address your problems.  The evening flew by, and I can't wait to go again!

review.author: Jonn H K.
review.description:
Summary: This school is super awesome - unless you are bored, there is no need to read the following completely biased review by an alum who is infatuated with the school.

Vanderbilt has been a wonderful school for me as a student and as an alum. I make a point to serve on an industry panel and talk to students to help as Vanderbilt helped me financially to graduate without debt and professionally to collaborate on many cool projects. Vanderbilt believes in the mission to educate without student loans by assisting any way they can. My nephew and niece both graduated without debt as well. 

Professors are tough notch. Yeah, there are a few exceptions but overall the school cares about the quality education for the students, and professors are available and willing to help. 

We rarely have a good football team, and I'm proud that we don't follow the model of chasing money in athletics. I like Vanderbilt as an academic institution. Besides we are pretty good at tennis, golf, baseball and bowling, I hear. 

The expansion of school made the campus to be scattered about in Nashville, but overall it is a pretty campus. Since my graduation, the buildings have been upgraded. When I was there, bathrooms smelled like it...and I was ok with it. Buildings look old and smelled it too. And I liked that too.  Now many buildings are modern and clean. I like it ok, but I miss the old quaint feel of a classic American institution. 

If you want a small school feel with top academic reputation, diversity, and cool college experience, I recommend Vanderbilt!

review.author: Meanole M.
review.description: Vanderbilt University is right next to the Parthenon. We drove a few blocks and then parked and walked.This is a beautiful campus, but not as nice as our alma mater, UF. The campus is dominated by the university's medical facilities. They are fairly modern buildings. We had a great post Thanksgiving walk and were on our way to the huge park we were originally looking for.

review.author: Joyce T.
review.description: Historical beautiful campus. Felt a little Harry Potteresque with the manicured green grass, mature trees, stone architecture, brick offices and clean walkways.\n\nThere are more modern basic buildings and surrounding road/dorm construction, but nothing that will deny you access.

review.author: V B.
review.description: You should be aware that the Office of student accounts will not speak to a parent or student on the phone, is not available by email and will not explain any bills (75K +/year) because they have "thousands of accounts" and "have internal and external audits. Maybe they are so busy with the audits that they can't explain a bill. They are always, however, willing to take your money, just won't tell you what it is for. If you don't pay in full there are high monthly fees. They don't tell you that there are payment plans because most of the students who attend are wealthy. I've never seen a school that was so secretive about charges. I would urge you to consider a school that is more transparent in its charges and willing to speak to students and parents for even 5 minutes to explain charges.

review.author: L S.
review.description: Took a tour here for our child who is starting to look at colleges. Have always loved Vandy and thought highly of it. The campus is very pretty and staff were friendly. It was nice to walk campus with a guide taking a peek into residence hall, dining hall, etc. Unfortunately Vandy has fallen prey to the woke culture. They spent a LOT of time really focusing on their 1st slide of the presentation, strongly emphasizing how committed they are to equity, LGBTQ, BLM, etc. It wasn't that they value diversity and inclusion. It was a huge helping of identity politics that continued beyond slide 1, being reinforced multiple times through the presentation as well as along the tour. The LGBTQ flag was in the window leading up to the meeting, hanging in the residence hall, & regularly displayed around campus. Doesn't matter to me what someone's sexual preference may be, but I want to pick a university based on their educational quality and that seemed to take a back seat in the discussions.  On a side note, the flags were the old version rather than the newer one so makes me wonder if this isn't all just an effort at virtue signaling.  Not saying Vandy is out, but it's a shame to see their focus shift so significantly.

review.author: Julio H.
review.description:
We came here as tourists, not students or faculty, to check out the area. My traveling companion is very impressed with things collegiate, so we decided to step into these grounds.

We entered through West End Avenue and parked. Cornelius was there to welcome us. It was exciting to see him. 

We walked around, imbibing in the sophisticated thought, and transported ourselves to the past. The buildings definitively improve the proper use of your imagination. I found interesting that the Psychological Sciences Building has designs that remind me of the Freemasons, but it is all in perfect accord. 

We enjoyed our time here.

review.author: Scott S.
review.description: Beautiful campus and a top notch university located in a great city.  Honestly what more could you ask for.  Easy to get lost as all the buildings look the same.  Asked security for directions and they happily provided them.  Campus is open if you want to walk around and bask in the beauty of its surroundings.  I recommend it.

review.author: Chris B.
review.description: Beautiful campus and the tour was very thorough. Interesting to see since a "green" campus with an amazing amount of trees. Tour guides did a great job of answering everyone's questions and getting us around.

review.author: Ben C.
review.description: Awesome school, can't lie to you. Been an amazing 4 years: great campus, great food, great staff.

review.author: Stacy W.
review.description: Not that impressive. The kids who go here are pretty bland and not looking to have much fun.

review.author: Matthew H.
review.description:
Located in Nashville, Tennessee, Vanderbilt University is one of America's most elite higher education institutions. With slightly under 7,000 undergraduates and an acceptance rate hovering around 11%, some of the smartest minds across the world flock to Vanderbilt for a wonderful education. 

I find it repulsive that anyone would give this University anything less than a five star rating. There are few faults, if any, that I can find wrong with this wonderful place. The campus is beautifully manicured whenever I have visited, and the staff and students alike are so welcoming. 

There is a lot of construction going on, and as someone who works in commercial real estate, I love it! 

Vanderbilt will continue to nurture amazing talent both in the classroom and on the athletic fields. The students are some of the happiest out of any university, according to Princeton Review. Even, the cafeteria food is great!

One thing I will say is that Memorial Gymnasium either needs air-conditioning or to be torn down!

review.author: Kiersten C.
review.description:
I graduated from Vandy in 2014 and have gone back at least twice a year for the last three years. I love love loved this place. 

The students were phenomenal, the staff were great, the campus is gorgeous. Our cafeterias are consistently ranked as top in the nation. No one goes to yelp for a university review, but I promise you have a fan here. 

If you're ever in town in late March/early April I recommend checking out InVUsion hosted by the Multicultural Leadership Council. It's a huge cultural showcase on alumni lawn that features performances, free food, and diy activities from the multicultural orgs on campus - all FREE

review.author: Evan K.
review.description: Nice staff, atrociously late for our appointment. We were there for an ultrasound at 10:40. They asked us to check In 20 minutes early so we did. Over an hour later we checked to make sure we got checked in. Then they brought us to another waiting room where we waited an additional hour. They didn't take my wife's BP, height or weight. We had a separate appointment at 1:00 PM over the phone where we checked in 10 minutes early as requested. Again, the staff signed into the appointment almost ten minutes late. Nice people and we assume they are busy, with that being said, we wished there was more care for the appointment times they set.

review.author: Robert D.
review.description: I am just visiting, but should admit very surprised and impressed with Vanderbilt University facilities, labs, and hospital. It is a cultural shock for me to see how nice are people here, super positive experience, loved it!

review.author: Josh M.
review.description:
I have been to Vanderbilt university a lot. I tend to visit 2 times a year. I have spoken at vandy. Also have been here just for a visit. Vanderbilt university is located in Nashville TN in the heart of the city. There is a lot of really great eateries with in walking distance. 

There are a lot of good looking girls at this school. For a more prestigious school I'm shocked at the girls. The frats and sororities are nice and welcoming. The campus is really nice to just walk around. 

Being from NY I would say vandy reminds me of Yale or NYU education wise more prestigious.

review.author: Jesse Q.
review.description: Best hospital hands down I only let down is as you get older even thou they are a research organization its limited in helping older people other than that it's a awesome place

review.author: Jennifer B.
review.description:
This is a beautiful university located only 1.5 from downtown Nashville. From downtown, the walk cuts across the midtown area that has a unique cross section of local bars and restaurants. I love that there are neighboring bars called Winners and Losers on the way.

The campus was lush and green, a luxury compared to where I've lived in CA, CO, and TX. The students all seemed very friendly and weren't shy offering their help so I could find the building I was looking for. 

I came to the school as a prospective student and toured the geology department. They are grouped in with environmental studies. They have some great lab space located in the basement and professors that are passionate about their field.

review.author: D D.
review.description: I'd go here for an education. Beautiful campus, new dorms look nice, food at student cafeteria was pretty good. Near many restaurants, bars, and coffee shops.

review.author: Joe S.
review.description: We stopped by for a walk and I didn't find any information or building explanations like other universities!

review.author: Robert L.
review.description: I love this university. I have always been a huge Vanderbilt fan. I love going to sporting events at Vanderbilt either at Hawkins Field, Memorial Gym or Vanderbilt Stadium. Vanderbilt is the Harvard of the SEC. Being the best academic school in the SEC is great but you get to see all the amazing other SEC athletic programs. SEC baseball and SEC football is the best conference in the land. The students at this university are pretty friendly and outgoing unlike most elite schools. I love Vanderbilt's campus in the Fall, its an amazing place to be. If you are a good student in HS or just visiting Nashville. Check this campus out its awesome. GO VANDY.

review.author: Jodi C.
review.description: Even if you don't play the piano, stop in here for a lesson from Kerry! I'm visiting from out of town and I've learned so much in only a few lessons that I want to buy a piano and start playing in my home town!

review.author: DegThai T.
review.description: After looking around finding music class for our daughter. We decided to join Nashville Music Academy. And it's our best decision ever! \nMy daughter is taking piano class with Mrs.Tatia Rose. She is very excited every time she go to the class. Mrs.Tatia is so kind, friendly and very professional. Now, We are so happy and know that our daughter is in a really good hand for her music lesson.

review.author: Matt W.
review.description: Centrally located near the heart of music city. Staff is very friendly and knowledgeable (many of which are working musicians in the Nashville area). Very affordable with a lovely environment to take lessons in. Communication by staff is A+++. Highly recommended for all ages!

review.author: M. H.
review.description: I attended 2011-2013.  I already had a couple degrees from a large university, so this was not my first higher education experience.  I was changing professions to nursing and this was the closest school.  OCCC is very small - smaller than the high school I attended.  But I do not think that means the education is poor, but quite the opposite.  Most of the instructors were knowledgeable and interested in student success, and teacher: student ratios are good.  (I found one core instructor to be quite incompetent, as did the other students I was with.  That happens everywhere, though.)  Lab instructor Lynn is great.  Our clinical instructors varied quite a bit and were mostly good.  I obtained a BSN after and feel the program at OCCC was better (the BSN was from a reputable school).  I think OCCC is especially good for students who prefer the smaller campus, such as home school and some high school students who appreciate a good education but don't want to be swallowed up in a huge university or others who just don't like massive waves of students to navigate.  I give it 4.5 stars, but round up to 5.

review.author: Nathaniel L.
review.description:
Nate.
I am a novice surfer. I have only been surfing twenty seven times. My name is Nate. I ride a seven foot six inch bodyglove brand board that I bought off of their website. My board is called the "daily." It has a plastic tri fin guidance system. Maybe you have seen me wiping out down at one of the beaches near Newport. I have a short story for you.
I was surfing up at Otter Rock. I had only surfed that beach twice at this point. I was putting my wetsuit on in the parking lot when I saw Russell the south beach surf shop owner guy pull up in this little blue car. I waved and thought nothing of it. It turned out that Russell was teaching surfing that day.
I walked down the steps to the beach and looked at the waves.
I decided where to put in and I stepped in the water. I put my board into the surf and paddled out and started trying to line a wave up.
There were a lot of people there. It turned out that I had walked right into Idaho's spring break rush. There were a lot of surfers there of all different experience levels.
I was having a lot of fun. Everything was fine . I surfed for several hours with out incident.
The waves were getting smaller at this point. Most of the real surfers, you know the guys on the short boards with the side bites were really far out or at least far out for me. Since the ocean was a lot calmer now I paddled towards them. I wanted to see if I could be in the big boys club for a little bit and see if I could make a little surfer friend. It gets lonely surfing by yourself.
I kept paddling. This weird undercurrent swept my board out towards the rocks. It felt like I was being swept out to sea. How could this be possible. Just a moment ago I was going to try to join the big boys club. I had lost total control of my board and I raced past the more experienced surfers very quickly. The look on their faces was of concern. This other guy who was a little younger than I was also got caught. We were both paddling hard and we were not budging an inch. We kept looking at each other as if to say "what are we going to do now? I don't want to be shark bait." Neither of us said a word. I was embarrassed and scared.
Panic was almost setting in. To make it worse the only way out of this if we got any further out would be for a coast guard helicopter to pick us up. It would be embarrassing being on the six ocklock news.
I saw Russell paddle straight towards me out of nowhere. Russell told me that I was being swept out to sea. He put his foot on my board and guided me. Russell pointed me where to paddle and then yelled "PADDLE, PADDLE!" I paddled hard.
I got back to shore. Russell saved the other guy as well. Russell had been watching us the whole time. It turned out he told all of the guys in front of us to paddle in because of the undercurrent. He probably saved the coast guard guys a trip and he saved us all the humiliating experience of being on the news.
I was shocked. I went home and hosed my wetsuit and gloves and booties off. I hung up my wetsuit and gloves and let them drip dry on the front porch and then I slept for an hour.
After my little nap I decided to take the next day off. I told my mom what happened and we both agreed that I was a lucky ducky.
Two days later after surfing the south jetty in Newport I went to Russell's surf shop nearby. Russell told me that I really was in danger of being swept out to sea. In the moment I wasn't sure exactly what was happening. I bought some special soft top wax for my surfboard and thanked my lucky stars. I drove home. Here I am. I am a lucky guy and Russell knows surfing.
This is a one hundred percent true story. This happened in front of at least one hundred people.
Yours truly.

Nathaniel Lentz, general manager of Springside Tree Farms.

review.author: May J.
review.description: The owner is very knowledgeable and kind. He is a great person to rent from or get surfing lessons, professional yet warm and personable. His prices are also reasonable. Went with my family and we all found something for everyone of different ages to wear and surf with.

review.author: A.J. F.
review.description: Took a surfing lesson for the first time with Russell and had a blast!  He taught me so much in just one lesson and is incredibly knowledgeable about surfing.  He makes you feel completely safe in the Ocean and even got me catching waves and standing up on my board in my first lesson.  His shop is super cool and has everything you need.  I picked up a fantastic wetsuit that keeps me super warm and is much easier to get on/off than the others I tried, plus a great board and all the extras.  I give South Beach Surf Shop my highest recommendation!

review.author: Finn L.
review.description: Got more then just a board from Russell at South Beach Surf Shop. Russell gave me great insight on places to surf in Newport area which was key to maximize my time in the area for limited time I had for surfing. Also learned about JRM boards that are being shaped out of his shop as well as some killer up cycle surfboard art Russell is doing. South Beach Surf Shop is the spot to go to get hooked up for boards, lessons, and surf art.

review.author: Justin H.
review.description: This shop is amazing. Don't go anywhere else. Russell was extremely friendly and he helped all 4 of my friends get wetsuits and boards. He took his time and made sure the wetsuits would fit each one of them, and the boards that he has are brand new and perfect for learning. This shop has amazing customer service and Russell really knows his stuff. I ran into him while surfing and he stopped what he was doing just to give my friends a quick surf lesson. He will go out of his way to make sure you have the best surfing experience. He also recommended szabos steakhouse to us for dinner after surfing and they had really good food and all for a good price.

review.author: Johanna M.
review.description: This was a fantastic experience.  I wanted to work on my photography skills in a low key, personalized way.  Jaymi didn't disappoint.  Before our outing she asked me about my skill level, what my interests were and made sure that my photography adventure really fit me.  Our all day adventure started off with wonderful sunrise light and sea creatures.  Once my brain was full of new info, not only about photography, but the natural world around Newport, we had a great lunch with time to review what I'd learned and what I can practice in the future.  More fun in the forest and a wonderful finish back at the coast made this a perfect day.\n\nI'd highly recommend Jaymi Heimbuch as your photo tour guide if you're traveling through the Newport Oregon area or looking for a patient and inspiring wildlife and landscape photography professional.

review.author: Jamie C.
review.description:
I recently spent a full day session with Jaymi Heimbuch of Oregon Coast Photo Tours expanding my photography skills on the beautiful Oregon coast and would recommend this experience to anyone at any skill level who is interested in growing their photography skills as a hobbyist or professional.

Prior to our session Jaymi and I spoke at length about what skills and knowledge I had hoped to gain during our outing. All aspects of our conversation were addressed and incorporated just as we discussed. I was very impressed with the location choices, overall itinerary, and exceptional guidance that Jaymi provided throughout the day. Every detail and minute of our session was well thought out and planned with my goals and interests in mind.

I can't begin to express how grateful I am to have connected with someone as talented, sharp, and ethical as Jaymi. She is more than just a phenomenal photographer and instructor. She is a phenomenal naturalist and human being. Just a few days removed from our amazing session and I am seeing immediate improvements not just in my photography skills but in my mindset and outlook as a wildlife and conservation professional as well.

review.author: Keith N.
review.description: The best investment you can make in your photographer journey is to take a class from Jaymi. She is a superb photographer, excellent teacher and a lot of fun to be with. She converted me from 'automatic' to 'manual' mode, showed me how to frame the photo and consider different angles, helped me improve my lightroom skills, etc. I can't wait to continue this journey with her.

review.author: Erin P.
review.description:
Jaymi did the impossible. She took an experienced photographer and an always-on-automatic shooter and gave them both the same incredible experience. She worked magic in coordinating diverse goals with tides and the sunset schedule and found nearly deserted beaches for us to shoot on. My cousin and I both got shots that we are proud of and will treasure forever. Even the experienced photographer learned a lot! 

No matter your level of experience, having someone who knows specific locations and how to compose the best photos at those locations is a great addition to any vacation. You get a tour of the area, see some of the locals-only spots, and get tips for other places to go on your own. But Jaymi makes all this special with her fun personality, her low-key suggestions, and her passion for photography. I can't wait for my next trip to the Oregon coast so that I can take another tour with her.

PS. Her snacks ROCK.

review.author: Sam M.
review.description:
Absolutely amazing experience!  Jaymi was responsive to our interests, even repeatedly changing the itinerary on the fly to fit what subjects we were interested in, the weather, what techniques we wanted to learn, and our stamina level.  And our stamina was the issue, not hers: she'd happily shoot with us from 5am until dark.

Jaymi is a true expert in lots of areas.  She showed us new photo techniques and ways to use our gear better, even though we thought our skills were already pretty advanced going in.  We even asked for a lesson in post-processing on the fly without giving her a chance to prepare and she obliged and really helped us out.  As a local area expert, she took us to great locations for wildlife, landscape, and macro, managing travel times and park permits and always getting us in and out before holiday-weekend crowds descended.  She's an expert in local biology, too:  she explained everything from fungus and plant species to seal behaviors to tidepool ecosystems to animal tracks to identifying bird calls.

I simply can't imagine a better guide.  Jaymi's deep expertise combined with her gentle teaching style, unfailing energy, and go-get-em attitude made her an absolute blast to hang out with.

review.author: Steve P.
review.description: Jaymi agreed to try to satisfy both the landscape lover and the wildlife lover in our morning session on the coast just south of Yachats.  The day started with her cheery early morning greeting with hot beverages and snacks.  We ventured onto the beach at low tide and got a good start to the landscape side of things.  Jaymi was thoughtful and helpful in suggesting methods and views on a beach that we had entirely to ourselves.  We then started looking for wildlife and met with success beyond any possible expectation.  We found American Dippers searching for breakfast, Oystercatchers and a Western Gull finishing of an ochre sea star.  But the highlight of the day was coming across a coyote feasting on a harbor seal in a tide pool!   We highly recommend Jaymi and Oregon Coast Photo Tours!!!

review.author: Just M.
review.description: This place is amazing!! Prices are reasonable & the glassworks are stunning. I recommend this place for unique floats. He does shipping. A fun area of Newport also!!!

review.author: Kim V.
review.description: What a great experience.  Jeff is super friendly and very patient.  There is a wide variety of things you can give a try at.  We each made a float and would definitely do it again!   Throughly worth it.

review.author: Julie E.
review.description: We had a fantastic experience at The Hot Shop!  Our 2 grandsons had their first lessons in glass blowing.  Jeff was patient and gave them the perfect balance of instruction and assistance while allowing them to create their own beautiful pieces.\nHis wife was very sweet and helpful as we chose some additional items to take home for gifts.  I highly recommend The Hot Shop for lessons and shopping!

review.author: Bill K.
review.description: My wife's gal pal insisted we visit the Hot Shop while on the coast as she has in the past and we're so glad we did. Jeff, the owner/artisan showed us countless blown glass pieces and let us choose our colors, size, etc. He is the consummate teacher as he walked us through each step of the process and didn't 'direct' us. One 'student' at a time so we got his undivided attention. We had a wonderful time creating 'floats' that we'll always enjoy displaying in our home. After we see them 'cooled' tomorrow, he'll safely ship them to ur home.\nA stop at this artist's shop to blow your own glass art is a must!

review.author: Keith And Betty R.
review.description:
Took a trip to the Oregon Coast and spent some amazing hours at the Hot Shop with Jeff.

My son was able to create original glass pieces, with Jeff providing wonderful instruction and guidance. Through heating, rolling, twisting, and shaping glass with various tools and the use of special techniques, my son was able to bring his designs to beautiful life. Everything was done safely and in a supportive environment. 

This was definitely the highlight of our time spent in Oregon. Artisans like Jeff help to create magical memories and give Oregon its character and unique verve.

Please support incredible art and artists!

review.author: Jay F.
review.description:
My wife and I celebrated our anniversary on the coast and decided we wanted to take a glass blowing class. We had stopped by the place in Lincoln City (Taft) several times in the past. I searched yelp for something closer to Seal Rock (where we were staying) and The Hot Shop came up. 

We are SOOOOO glad we decided to go here. Jeff was a great teacher and allowed us to work the glass through the entire process. From shaping to adding color to forming the float and finally blowing it up to size. Jeff provided guidance and instruction the entire time allowing us to complete our own masterpiece. 

If you want to stand beside an employee while they create your piece and allow you to blow at the very end, then you'll be satisfied with the shop up the road. BUT if you want to work hands on with shop owner and artist Jeff by your side, then The Hot Shop is hands down the place for an amazing experience!!!

review.author: Kate H.
review.description: Jeff was so amazing and helpful, and his family was just the sweetest! We did three classes and due to coast highway construction (go figure eh?) we were fifteen minutes late. With a quick phone call he was completely understanding about it and he had left plenty of time after our appt until his next one so we still got to do all three of our pieces. \n\nHe was very knowledgeable and his teaching techniques were very easy to follow and understand. He helped us newbies make some very beautiful glass pieces to take home with fond memories attached to them.

review.author: Eric F.
review.description: Great time again at the Hot shop. Jeff is very patient, safe and my girls have learned a lot about this fine art... I hope you stop in and take this informative class and/or visit the studio....

review.author: Kristin H.
review.description: Incredible experience learning how to blow glass. My husband and I truly enjoyed each and every minute of it. The owner of the store is patient, gives great instruction, and the one on one class was a great value for the time spent and product you make. I would highly recommend visiting his shop to purchase any of his work, but for the best part, spend the time and money and have a one of a kind experience.

review.author: Karen H.
review.description: The best hot shop experience, Jeff was so kind and personable.  He involved us enough so that I felt it really was my piece. The glass holds 16 oz of water, it is so beautiful.

review.author: Kathryn O.
review.description: We don't give out 5 stars freely but Jeff deserves that and more. We stumbled into the shop and discovered we could blow our own glass! Jeff talked to us first finding out what we wanted in shape, color and size. He listened to us about translucency and opaqueness. He really listened to what we each wanted to do. Jeff was the greatest teacher, walking us thru each step, explaining everything and telling us how good we were doing. He had his hand in the process enough so that there would be a good outcome. A fantastic souvenir, bowls we made ourselves!  We pick them up tomorrow morning. Glass blowing is an art and you can't predict the exact result but we did it ourselves!!

review.author: Food E.
review.description: This was by far the best expirence I have had blowing glass. Jeff, the owner is a great teacher and is very knowledgeable on both the art and it's history. He is also an amazing artist. You will not only learn the how to, but he will also drop some historical facts on you as you work. It was very interesting. He also lets you do about 98% of the work on your project, unlike other shops. But at any time, if you ask, he will step in if you are not feeling comfortable with any part. This shop is truley family owned and operated. And you can tell, both Jeff and his wife are very personable and they seemed to really care about their customers. Prices are just a bit lower than other shops in the area, which is nice. And he is much more flexible on the projects he offers. What you get for your money is a great time, an education and an outstanding project piece you made and will enjoy for years to come. If you are anywhere near Newport OR. And want to do some glass blowing, this is the place to go. We made 5 projects and everyone was very pleased how they came out.

review.author: Jane D.
review.description: This is the place to go to try your hand at glass blowing. Jeff the owner and instructor is wonderful! He is informative, patient and very personable. There were 4 of us who made a glass project and really enjoyed the class. We all were very pleased with the results. The experience was very pleasant and enjoyable. We were able to take pictures and videos. Next time we are in Newport we will return for another class.

review.author: Colleen M.
review.description: My sister's boys were here to visit and I have to tell you that they had an awesome experience!!  Jeff was very encouraging, thoroughly explaining the process and guiding the boys through the process letting them create their own beautiful pieces.  \nThey felt so good about the experience talking about it through dinner and I believe for years to come!  Also his shop has incredible pieces that Jeff the owner has created for sale and I can tell you that after working in a glass gallery myself in Nye beach his inventory and prices are amazing!!  Going back for Christmas gifts!!

review.author: Timothy M.
review.description: Great people. Refreshing atmosphere for a glass shop. Easy 5 stars for price and personal attention.

review.author: Good B.
review.description: A great visit with our teenage boys. We watched a glass blowing class and it made for very interesting time. It is a very cool place. We walked out with a beautiful black glass bowl.

review.author: Kaiya W.
review.description: adequate education. deffo met some unsavory characters here. i dont alwyas go but when i do it can be fun sometimes. will update when we figure out what colleges i get into.

review.author: Sara F.
review.description: My good friend had an awful experience with this place, so I decided I'd go and see if that was how they usually treated people. I came in on a Tuesday, the place was massive! I have never seen a restaurant so big. I wandered the many corridors for about fifteen minutes looking for where the food was actually served. Then a bearded, walkie-talkie bearing man stopped me, he appeared a little concerned. He asked me if I was someones grandmother. I was shocked! Yes, I am a grandmother, but how old do I really look? So rude! Then he wanted me to get a visitors badge, when I told him I was only here for the food. He got really nice, and brought me to this office-looking room. He made a call and I was taken out to a bus where they hauled me off to be "evaluated". What an odd experience with horrible customer service. That's 2 out of 2 bad visits, Would not recommend.

review.author: Candi S.
review.description: Nice prices for glass blowing.  Our instructor was very friendly and informative.  It was a really great memory to make with my kid

review.author: Star S.
review.description: 7 years later, and we were back! This time I took my 10 and 12-year-old nephews and they were able to make their own float. This place is still freaking fantastic and they both really enjoyed learning about bowling glass. The instructor was the owner and he was one of the best teachers I've ever seen. He really paid attention to each kids abilities and what they felt comfortable in doing. He demonstrated really well and was very in tune with each of my nephews. The older and taller nephew definitely got to do a little more than the younger and I think that was excellent! Definitely try and stop by here if you have the time.

review.author: Leisyka P.
review.description: We had so much fun blowing glass this weekend for Mother's Day. Such a wonderful glass blower and teacher. She took great care to ensure we all got exactly what we wanted. We made a reservation for 3 of us to make a heart and wave shaped paperweights that turned out beautiful. Don't miss this awesome experience when you are visiting Newport.

review.author: JeffnNikki M.
review.description: Thoroughly enjoyed our glass making experience with Tonya at Oregon Glassworks.   Obviously we aren't the ones making the glass into its final form but it was a blast being a part of the process  and  learning how it all comes tougher into a lovely piece of art. We highly recommend the experience.

review.author: Amanda D.
review.description: Great shop! We did glass blowing here as a group and the worker was super patient was all five of us (we did it individually). Our glass turned out great.

review.author: Jer C.
review.description: My second time around. Always a pleasure....highly recommend.  Memorializing my son and was treated very sensitvely.

review.author: Lisa H.
review.description: Very professional business with friendly and helpful staff.  Had a wonderful time creating my own work of art with a little assistance from a pro glasswerker (is that a word?).  Lessons are scheduled for two people at a time, so it was a perfect activity for myself and a friend.  Highly recommended!  They ship, and I can hardly wait for my creation to arrive.

review.author: Dayna C.
review.description: Our morning at Oregon Coast Glassworks was the most memorable experience from our recent trip.  We have traveled the globe but we've never had the opportunity quite like this one.  Few activities appeal to all three of my teenagers but designing and making their own custom glass blown art was a huge hit with everyone.  Today, we picked up the finished pieces and they are spectacular.  I am so grateful for the time and patience the shop owners/artisans took to teach my kids about their craft and integrate them meaningfully into each step of the process.  This shop is Native American owned and operated.  I will long cherish not only the glass art we carry home but the stories they told of how their Indigenous culture and customs are integrated into their amazing creations.  If you are anywhere near Newport, visit this shop.  It's worth calling ahead or visiting their website to book an appointment if you want to make something yourself.  You can also choose from some of the beautiful pieces for sale.  Even with three kids and two dogs in tow - we couldn't resist buying several items (in addition to our custom pieces) to take home as gifts and for display.

review.author: Chris K.
review.description:
Her name is T.  She was astounding as our guide to make glass with my Grandparents and our children. You can book a glass making session.  You have the option of choosing multiple styles of glass ornaments and colors.  The price is well worth the experience of making your own glass.  Astounding!  

Please keep inspiring children and all to make glass, and keep the art.  

It was very much a pleasure to be in the shop, learn, create, purchase and walk away with an memory none of us will ever forget.

review.author: Lynn S.
review.description: We had such a lovely experience.  It goes fast (15 minutes maybe).  With masks and the kilns it can be difficult to hear.  Our younger kiddos loved watching.

review.author: Jamie D.
review.description:
Our family made a special trip to Oregon Coast Glassworks to blow glass together. It's been on our to-do list for a while and after reading so many amazing yelp reviews we decided to give it a try.

First, their store is SUPER conveniently located right off the highway coming into town. There's parking on both sides of the building. 

The store is HUGE! And decorated beautifully. Lots of unique pieces for sale.

The gentleman that helped us blow our glass was awesome! He really took his time to make sure our experience was the best. He even showed my son how to make a glass horse after we were done with our session. 

Such a great experience!! Highly recommend!!

review.author: Allison R.
review.description:
Without a doubt, hands down, the best part of our family trip to Newport. 
We entered the store with three young children and were prepared for the evil eye, but it never came.  Everyone at Oregon Coast Glassworks was friendly, kind, and informative.
There are chairs to watch the professional glassblowers craft their art, or you can take a class.
We decided to create a float and had a fantastic time being guided through this process.  It was very hands on and everyone enjoyed it immensely.
This will be our number one stop the next time we are in Newport!

review.author: Jessica M.
review.description:
My 13-year-old sister visits me every summer in Portland and I try to come up with new and fun activities to do together. This summer, we tried Oregon Coast Glassworks and it could not have been a better experience. We had an individual glass blower expert show each of us how to make two unique pieces of blown glass--I made a beautiful float that was the perfect gift for my grandmother this Christmas; and my sister made a super cool paperweight with a wave inside that sits on her drawer at home. 

Our glass blower, Steve, was so much fun to spend time with and helped our pieces turn out beautifully. We were even running a little bit late to our appointment, but they were so nice and understanding about it. Because our glass pieces take 24 hours to cool, Oregon Coast Glassworks was kind enough to mail them to us as soon as they were ready. What a treat!

There are a ton of glass blowing workshops along the Oregon Coast, but Oregon Coast Glassworks is definitely the one to go with. It will simply be a wonderful experience.

review.author: Amanda I.
review.description: What a fun experience for our family! Friendly staff. I noticed a lot of glass blowing places in town and on our drive to Yachats. It's not cheap, but that's show business!

review.author: Katrina H.
review.description: This was one of the coolest activities we have done here in Newport (and there are some really fun things to do)! Some friends had done it earlier in the day and we were able to walk right in, sign up, and learn how to make a float in 30 minutes! The teachers are great...very patient and encouraging, and the fact that we walk away with a piece of art (after letting it cool for a day in the shop) is so rad! Thank you for sharing your studio with the public!

review.author: Marsha S.
review.description: This was such an awesome experience. Thank you T, Steve and Wendy!  So much fun. We will definitely be back.

review.author: Kristen D.
review.description: This place is alot of fun. My parents booked an appointment for my birthday and it was so cool. The students that teach you Joanie and John from HI were so chill and helpful it didnt make me feel dumb for not knowing what I was doing\n Robin was very nice when we came and picked up our floats and my boyfriend wasnt satisfied with his she told him that he needed to redo it. Which was pretty cool that they truly want you to leave happy.\nWe recommend to everyone!

review.author: Stacey T.
review.description: Wow wow wow!   T was our gaffer and teacher and she rocked!  She helped my son and daughter make beautiful one of a kind floats!  We can't wait to pick them up!  The best souvenir we've ever gotten anywhere!!!!!  The whole process doesn't take long but is so informative and cool!  I wish we had something like this at home! \n\nWow! Just picked up the floats and they are beautiful!

review.author: Edie R.
review.description: When a friend of mine made plans to blow glass, I was excited, even though I had done it in the past. But John made it even more fun.  He has extensively studied glass and was a plethora of knowledge. My end project was beautiful. I highly recommend Oregon Coast Glassworks.

review.author: Jacqueline S.
review.description: We came in a group of 5. All of us made either floats or lampshades. The staff made sure our pieces came out nicely. They also explained every step in the process. We had a grand time and love our glasswork!

review.author: Nicky R.
review.description: My cousin goes there she said it's a good school but now she doesn't go to the school anymore

review.author: Tara B.
review.description: This is a great hands on learning environment! Between the touch pool, the friendly octopus display, and the hands on science experiments no one goes home having been bored. \n\nI as the adulted loved the friendly octopus. My daughter loved playing with the wave maker and erosion pools. Definitely a revisit every time we are in the area and have an hour or more.

review.author: Greg C.
review.description:
My post Covid review:

It was 4pm, an hour before HMSC closes.  We got to the round-about, but there were these tall red street pylons where you are supposed to enter the parking lot.  

Gee...maybe they don't want any more visitors?  We went slowly around the round-about a few times looking like morons, and noticed just a few cars in the parking lot, so we decided to just go for it...and avoid the pylons.  Once in the parking lot I looked back and saw a few other cars pausing and wondering if they should enter, but were not sure because of these pylons.

So now...a reservation is required.  Welcome to post covid where every attraction insists you download an "app" and make a reservation.   But no worry says the front desk girl..."just download the app, make a reservation, and....pay the $3 per person fee."   

Yes, the Hatfield Marine Science Center is no longer free.  

I'm not turned off by paying $3 per person, but having to download an app, and make a reservation when the building is almost empty at 4pm is ridiculous.  I'm sure somewhere along the way HMSC gets my email address and profiling privileges through that app for future promotions and discounts?  And I con't care for the "self-guided tour" via the app.  Feel free to call me a grumpy Oregonian already paying way too high taxes.

As far as the actual exhibits, we didn't go.  Disney apps are bad enough, and now local attractions are doing the same, I guess in the name of crowd control?    

I'll assume there still is an octopus in a big tank that you can fondle.  It's probably great for kids just like it was for the past 40 years.  Theres probably some new stuff too.

review.author: Jenni M.
review.description:
The Hatfield Marine Science Center has been a part of the Oregon State University system for 50 years now.

While it's specifically geared toward K-12 education, our little family found that it is informative for adults as well.

We wound up here thanks to the rain.

There are many hands-on educational activities - some better than others; however, the tidepool touch tanks were our daughters' favorite.

Admission is free, but donations are welcome at the spectacular octopus sculpture/money box.

Most of the staff I spoke to were volunteers. They were more than happy to share their knowledge and insight.

There was a small section about their use of a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) to investigate methane seeps. They had a short video about it - amazing stuff. More of that please.

TIP
- don't forget to view the "OctoCam" at night if you missed a regularly-scheduled feeding - that's when their in-house octopus is most active!

review.author: Michael M.
review.description:
This was a fun and FREE place.  I'm all about the aquariums and such, but this one is free, so we went here instead of to the expensive paid one.  

What a fabulous experience.  Lots of interactive stuff for the kiddos (and adults) and lots of great learning experiences all over the place.  

Takes at least an hour or more to actually see and do it all.  

Be sure to check out the TOTALLY AWESOME octopus tank!!!!

Staff and docents were spectacular.

review.author: Jackie M.
review.description: We had a blast here with our one year old daughter and can't wait to bring her back once her attention span is longer. There are touch tanks and other interactive exhibits to teach about various aspects of marine science. \n\nI was impressed with the beautiful fish tanks. While smaller than the Oregon Coast Aquarium, the science center is much more educational.

review.author: Quinn A.
review.description:
I could have watched the octopus for hours. It was a beauty, big red pacific variety, and as it dangled and contorted over a warm water vent, I was mesmerized.  I got up close to the glass as it grabbed then let go with dozens of suction cups. It floated like a gauzy curtain, then contracted into a tight ball. A couple of times it floated away then shot back, all of its tentacles trailing behind. I'm sorry you're a captive, but I'm so grateful to have met you. 

The rest of the place is Science! Weather, tides, erosion, species both ascendant and in decline. If I was a kid you wouldn't be able to pry me out of here. As an adult I wanted to donate the entire contents of my checking account. It's pay what you can admission here - be generous! 

Don't miss the large dock that arrived from Japan on the tide, a casualty of the tsunami.

review.author: Chrysanthemum A.
review.description:
Hatfield Marine Science Center is the less glamorous neighbor to the Oregon Coast Aquarium. It's centered mainly on research, it's part of OSU. There are educational exhibits on erosion, tsunamis, a touch tank, it's mainly about appealing to the children.

Unlike the Oregon Coast Aquarium, it's donation rather than admission. There is a little gift shop. It's not as exciting.

There's a prominent octopus display, along with "make your own tsunami" and a dock that was carried from Japan to Oregon in 2011. One can learn about tide pools, ocean acidification. It's a homespun little museum.

review.author: Lindsay R.
review.description:
This place is FREE and is amazing. My kids all loved it. Ranging from ages 5-15. There were things to explore, hands on displays, a really cool octopus who is mischievous. 

Volunteers were nice and welcoming. We enjoyed coloring together, and a whale presentation. 

We will definitely come back.

review.author: Frank W.
review.description: It is not every day that you go to an attraction and discover it is even better than you expected, but that is exactly what happened when we visited this science and education center.  There were a many interesting and informative exhibits, aquariums with a variety of sea life plus touch tanks that appeal to both young and old.  Each of the volunteers we encountered seemed were very nice and very well informed.  We spent almost 2 hours and I could have lingered longer had we not been pressed for time.  It was free, but a donation of $5 or more per person would be welcomed.

review.author: Stacey O.
review.description:
What a fun and informative place to spend a couple of hours exploring. 

It's really well laid out, so much information about marine life, fishing, tsunamis, aquariums; anything ocean relates really. There is a lot of really great displays with information to read but also some really fun interactive exhibits. We spent some time building tsunami resistant walls made of legos in a wave simulator. Once you build a wall you press a touch screen which simulates a wave. That's when you find out how sturdy your structure is! 

Another neat exhibit is a sand box which you can shift sand around to create mounds and a light above sense the topographical change and changes the sand colors in relation to the elevation of the mounds. So you can shift sand around to create blue lakes and waterways, mountains of green and even build high enough for the sand to turn white. You have to try it to understand. 

There are puzzles and questions for the kids as well as a touch pool. They have so many fish and sea creatures to look at in the aquariums as well. And a fun gift shop as well, of course. :)

Just a really fun place that is great for families, dates, kids, or anyone who is interested in marine life!

review.author: Susan D.
review.description:
This was MY favorite place on our vacation! Plus it's free! Donations encouraged $5 per person or $20 per family. 

We went to the aquarium when we left  my son noticed the sign and ask that we go. I assumed it was just an information center, but it's not, it's awesome! 

We learned about tsunamis, erosion, tectonic plates and the hands on topography sand table was the coolest thing ever! If I wasn't such a nice mom I would have pushed all the kids out of the way and played by myself! We also found not only Nemo, but Dory too!

review.author: Tricia O.
review.description:
A small free museum thanks to OSU, with plenty to see and do.

Plenty of hands on and interactive parts to each exhibit. We got up close to an Octopus and got to feel some on the animals that would be in a tide pool in their touch tanks. (Never thought about sea creatures being sticky underwater. That was pretty cool!)

If you are around for their outdoor tour, take it. You get to touch small crabs and hunt for shrimp in the mud using a shrimp gun!

review.author: Yolanda E.
review.description: Free to attend, but donations are appreciated.\nThe building is small but has enough activities to keep you or your kids occupied for at least 2 hours. There are clean and clear touch tanks, many fish to see, a couple skeletons on display, brain games to do, and a lot of information you can read or hear about from the volunteers (friendly and kind). Some of the fish are not labeled though.\nI recommend this place for people age 5 and up. My 4 year old was about a head too short for a couple of the activities.

review.author: Bob H.
review.description:
I was extremely pleased by the excellent work these people have done with their available resources. Excellent exhibits  that are interesting and educational with very well prepared staff!

Simply outstanding!

I gave them a decent donation and strongly support their efforts!
Please stop by and check this gem out!

Say 'Hi' to the Mamma octopus while you are there!

review.author: Michael H.
review.description: Our visit to the marine science center was fun and definitely worth the recommended donation.  The touch tank was a good experience and the displays on oyster cultivation and wave-generated electrical generation were educational.  The walk along the estuary trail is a great opportunity to see birds (including the osprey nest on a pole at one end of the trail).  We were disappointed, however, that there were no exhibits regarding research into climate change and its impacts on marine life and environments (although the oyster cultivation exhibits did briefly discuss the challenges to oyster cultivation due to ocean acidification resulting the absorption of too much carbon).  Some of the exhibits felt a bit dated, too.  Still, a good place to visit and well-worth the time of you're looking for some place interesting to spend a couple of hours in Newport.

review.author: B H.
review.description:
I will start by saying that this place is "free" but really it is donation based. I didn't realize this and I felt bad because I left all my personal belongs besides my phone at our beach rental. 

If you have kids under the age of 6 skip the aquarium and come here instead- it is right down the street- and if at all possible  don't go anywhere near the abomination known as the "Undersea Gardens". 

Aside from missing the larger marine animals and birds the selection of fish is very comparable. They even have a small handling tank with star fish. Just realize it is a working marine research center so don't expect theme park mascots and concession stands- it is for looking and learning. The place is also bigger than I thought it would be. 

I highly recommend this place above the other similar attractions in town.

review.author: Jen K.
review.description:
Don't forget to tip your walrus on the way out. 

There are two kinds of FREE activities...
**Type 1 - This is lame, but I'm not going to complain too much because after all it's free.
**Type 2 - I can't believe how great this is. Woo hoo!

The Hatfield Marine Research Center falls squarely under Type 2 for me. The fancy pants Newport Aquarium is just down the road, but admission for a family of four is roughly $75. It is a superior aquarium with more interactive exhibits, shows, etc., but that is a lot of money to spend on every trip to the area.

I've visited the Newport Aquarium before and will do so again, but I recommend alternating your visits with the Hatfield for a different set of activities. Your wallet will thank you. 

For a free museum it is pretty darn cool. It starts with the eight-armed receptionist. I love the description of the octopus on their website, "There have been many greeters, each with its own personality and level of enthusiasm for the job - and each with its own name, chosen by our visitors."  The tank is covered and flash photography is prohibited, but it is periodically opened during feeding time.

My boys' other favorite things were the Tidepool touch tanks with the vibrant sea anemone and the movies in the small auditorium. As a parent, I absolutely love visiting places where I don't feel obligated to stay if the kids' interest isn't there. So you can really make your visit as long or short as you please. 

The center is located on the south side of the bridge just minutes away from the historic Bayfront district. The store is also filled with a great selection of books and other merchandise. If only more museums could be so cheap and easy.

review.author: Shawn J.
review.description: My daughter had so much fun playing with all the interactive exhibits. Giving the center a donation is well worth what they have to offer. It's fun and educational for the kids. What more could you ask for? The staff is super friendly and knowledgable. They are all willing to make it a special experience for your little one

review.author: Michael G.
review.description:
Free? are you kidding me?  Yea been coming here for years!  If your lucky you can view the OSU marine vessel which docks here as well.  You can't get on it, but it is neat to see the research vessel the kids take to see for learning and exploration.  
The Octopus is the star attraction, however i like to poke the sea enemies, hahaha.  
There are many fish exhibits, some really up close views of the fish in various tanks.  We take almost two hours to see it all,  including a visit to the gift shop.  Sometimes pretty cool stuff.  They really lean towards the educational, so many items in the gift shop are great for the kids.  
We did make a donation as we left, it was well worth it!  
Tip-- it is really close to the rogue brewery so Lunch is very close!

review.author: Susan M.
review.description: If you are a science buff, head here. Lots of interesting info from the Oregon State University AND it is by donation. They have part of a dock from the Japanese 2011 earthquake that floated to Oregon and other interesting marine research. Also a touch pool for the kids.

review.author: Seth N.
review.description: Sam was such a great teacher. My wife and I took a lattice class with her and the finished products were just beautiful! She is a joyful woman who works at your pace and we had such a great time working with her. I would highly recommend her to anyone looking to take a class.

review.author: Leslie P.
review.description:
My husband gave me a gift of a photography class from Taylor Alexander Photography this past Christmas.  I was finally able to schedule it and take the class from Taylor herself this past March.   Not only did she teach me how to use the equipment I already owned more efficiently, but she opened my eyes to so much more as far as the type and style of photos I like to take.  Yes, this was a beginner's class, but now I have more of an overall understanding.  I had been doing so many wrong things for so long.

She is so down-to-earth and easy to talk to.  I loved the way she explained everything in layman's terms in addition to having a great guide book she provided.  She even offered help on choosing other equipment and gave me an example of what a photography release should look like.  

My only regret is that I didn't take the time to learn from her sooner.  I hope to take her full mentorship class soon to learn more about editing and business.  I would highly recommend taking a class from her as well as booking for photography needs.

review.author: Just A.
review.description:
There is so many things wrong about this place that makes me sick:
1. There are so many fights here and the principal doesn't do anything about it until the end of that fight
2. The teachers and staff never care about your child's grades, just themselves and their paychecks
3. If you hug another student, the staff will go at you saying you can't do that but if you have a boyfriend or girlfriend and you kiss them, the staff doesn't do anything about it.
4. There are so many kids nowadays vaping JUULs and NOBODY reports any of this stuff.
5. They leave the gymnasium doors open in the courtyard most mornings and afternoons.
6. Some staff (including some assistant principals) have been through multiple DUI or any federal charges and they get to go scott free instead of getting fired the 2nd time it happens.

review.author: Chris F.
review.description: This school is God awful. One problem with that is they don't make fresh food all day food is mostly reheat it is very occasional and conditional that you will get fresh food. Another problem with it is that they don't care about the students they care about getting him in and out they pass their own care if they feel they don't care it is just you you can have a few connections with a few teachers. Lastly I would like to point out that the environment doesn't feel very great the students there are the only fun part about it and the teachers there only a few teachers there then OK one positive note though is that those few teachers that are good it will make you your experience a little better there's one principle that is OK..

review.author: Quin S.
review.description:
Riverdale High School is a great high school. Honestly, as far as Tennessee schools go, the environment is great and the staff genuinely care about the students. Riverdale is nothing like the city schools that are great mis-mash of conflicting cultures and ideals which results in most kids attending private schools. Most students who attend Riverdale have parents who has attended Riverdale which means generations of people love this school.

There are many other little things about Riverdale that make it unique. Although there is definitely a presence of drugs, it's never become remotely violent. Most people who do drugs here mostly do weed, which isn't too harmful. Riverdale does have a no-tolerance policy on smoking, drugs, and drinking, so if any student starts to over-do, another student is likely to report them. Most of our problems with stupid Freshmen who think they're smart. Earlier this year two freshman football players that are not so decent people started vaping every morning before getting on the bus. It got so smelly that they got reported. On another incident, a freshman girl (often tries to be cool by bringing drugs), brought wine in a clear water bottle then shared it. She confessed and got off easy, while the boy she shared it with got suspension because he tried to lie about it being kool-aid. Kids who do serious things get sent to local alternative school.

Even with the drugs, Riverdale is very non-violent and very few people actually hate each other. Sure, gossip happens but it's mostly bark (no bite). Kids here seem to really enjoy talking to each other and the cliques aren't really that judgmental (excluding the racist hillbilly kids or the black kids, mostly girls, who act uppity). In fact, if you have some smarts, you can make a lot of fast friends in many different colors and interests. It's a very relaxed environment with very little drama.

Riverdale has several focuses. Mr. Nolan, who runs the school, is super lenient with his students. He tries to give them the best and really cares about every kid. 

If you're into machines and fixing uppin, Riverdale has a built in body shop to experiment on cars and other machinery. The ag department also offers a class on fixing farming equipment if you're into that. As far as electronics go, they also offer programming classes that make videos games and from my impression the students enjoy. During lunch the programming students can be found in the teacher's room watching videos or working on coding.

A good main focus is the student moral and sports. Mr. Nolan loves his rallies in the Gym and recently had the Gym redone as a result. He mainly focuses on rallies for the main sports teams such as football and our famous girls' basketball team that just won again this year. However unless students try to rise up and ask for less popular sports that we're also mega successful in to me recognized, sports like wrestling will be ignored. They are building another athletics building right now, and I don't exactly know what it is for. However, they already have a swimming pool, a gym, a track and football field, and among other things. 

The ag department has two separate parts. Small animal has an in-building collection of animals, including guinea pigs, rabbits, a corn snake, ferrets, degus, rats, mice, an iguana, two bearded dragons, and chinchillas. They also have rabbits outside in hutches. Large animal charge has sheep, goats, and I believe also works with cows and horses from other places. The ag department hosts FFA which is great for anyone interested in farming, livestock, or just going out and doing stuff with animals. They volunteer with the local shelter.

The science depart is also notable. They have a very active science club that will take outings to the local Barfield-Cresent park and volunteer to pick up trash, test water, etc. They also have taken field trips to go caving or canoeing. Mr. Hurt and Ms. Hargrove are super friendly. Mr. Hurt is arguably my favourite teacher as if you are interested in science and want to learn more about genetics in particular species or have him review scientific papers, he will take extra time to do that.

The language department is eh. They offer Latin, Spanish, and German. The current German teacher is very lenient, sometimes too much. I'm sure he's a great guy but he sometimes makes fun of his students when they're trying to learn. I've heard eh things about the Spanish teacher as well.

The English department is arguably one of the best. All the English teachers really, really care about their students and their grades. Many of the teachers who get the students with the higher test scores refuse to teach the state tests and instead have us actually writing papers with little worksheets to help us find textual evidence.

Overall, Riverdale is a great school with many upsides. It's an old school and looks run down, but the community makes it worth attending for fourth years. Recommended.

review.author: Korie H.
review.description: I am a certified cognitive trainer at LearningRx, and I love every minute of being at both centers. My co-workers, families, and students are all wonderful! LearningRx truly cares about each of it's clients and offers the best cognitive training around. If you're looking to boost your skills and make your brain reach it's potential, come see us!

review.author: Tish S.
review.description:
Just went to class today for an eight (8) hour session with Barrett and Kayla... and I must say I was dreading this.  However, I had a total blast!  This was a fun yet really educational session, and they managed to get the four and eight hour classes finished earlier than expected... which was a huge relief!  

The course was at the Holiday Inn Express on Chaffin Place in Murfreesboro,  (I give that place four and a half stars itself... not a full five as it didn't have a restaurant) and we could get coffee, avail ourselves of the food at the full breakfast bar... not a bad deal.  We played cool games in between the necessary videos, quizzes and tests, with a break about halfway through the four hour course, and a lunch hour for the eight hour... however, we managed to cover so much so quickly with retention that we were out of there hours earlier than expected. (We were a group of smart cookies!  Yay us!)

I can seriously say I learned a lot today.  Things have changed since I took drivers ed.  Barrett and Kayla are a great team... he's the teacher, and she's the silent but efficient partner; I really got a kick out of her as I know she's as charismatic as he is!  We got tips on how to efficiently deal with our completion certificates, got the fax numbers AND the number to call to follow up to make sure the Department of Safety actually HAD received it... I don't trust a fax transmittal sheet myself.  I want to know an actual PERSON has gotten that fax from that machine and done what they were supposed to do with it.  This is my driver's license we are talking about here!  So, they made sure each person knew what to do in their particular situation.

All in all?  I had a great day with a group of great people... exceptional teachers... an A+ school in all regards.  If one must attend this sort of thing?  This is the one!  I got a discount for signing up and paying online as well!!!

review.author: Barrett N.
review.description: This defensive driving course is unbelievable. I was dreading spending my Saturday off at a traffic school, but when I arrived I was happy to see a young instructor who kept the class engaged with knowledge and entertainment. If you want a great experience look no further. Hats off to the instructor!

review.author: Mary Kate E.
review.description:
I promised myself after I finished my master's degree that I would write a Yelp review about my school. This has been a long awaited review. I have been at MTSU since 2018. I completed my last year of my bachelor's, my master's, and in August - I start my doctorate. This school has been a saving grace for me as an adult learner. 

I can't say a single negative thing about my university. From the professors, the curriculum, to the overall student experience has been exceptional. For the education I am receiving, it is worth every penny. It's not an expensive education considering what I have learned and the village that has been behind me to thrive. 

If there was a downside to the university, I'd say parking services sucks and they are determined to collect your money. Watch out when you park and pay attention to ensure you park in the correct lot. If you don't - it is going to cost you extra money you don't want to unnecessarily spend. Speaking from recent experience, but I digress. I guess I have officially had my right of passage to receive a parking ticket.

MTSU is great for remote learning and easy to understand for those who might not believe that online education is a good fit for them. MTSU caters to those working folks who may not be able to dedicate their entire life to schooling and have other obligations outside of their educational career. I am one of them minus the pandemic. 

I completed my entire master's online in 3 semesters due to being a full-time student. It was the best way for my to utilize my time during very a very unpredictable year. I do not regret my decision to get it out of the way. The pandemic shifted a lot in our lives and this was the best track for me to take to thrive. 

Now, with my doctorate on the horizon, I look forward to working full-time while attending part-time. Recognizing the busy schedule that I will have; I could not ask for a better school to walk with me through this educational journey that I am about to endure.

review.author: Elizabeth H.
review.description: Only MTSU would promote people getting their undergrad, masters, and doctoral degree in the same place. Any university worth anything would disclose to students to go elsewhere upon finishing an undergrad. Because in the real world of academe, it is looked down upon for any single student to get all three degrees in the same place. It is one of those unwritten rules that no one at MTSU will volunteer. Otherwise, how would they make their money? That is all MT cares about--getting your money. MT will take your money and hustle you all the way.

review.author: Jay J.
review.description:
My father, Charles Johnson, died in 2006. I have not been able to move on, and maybe part of it is because he left behind unfinished business - litigation with MTSU or Middle Tennessee State University, his last office job before my mother's death and this lawsuit sent him into spiraling depression that convinced him to work construction and day labor jobs instead.

What happened to the student workers and construction workers who were exposed to asbestos all those years ago? I believe some of them may have developed or are beginning to develop symptoms related to asbestos exposure now, such as mesothelioma or lung cancer.
