Went to visit this campus to see my brother-in-law's graduation from Harding's physical therapy school. It was smart that they have 3 separate graduation ceremonies throughout the day for different departments. It is a very nice & well-kept campus, I will give them that.

Most of the reasons I don't like the school stem from hearing about my sister's & brother-in-law's experience here. For one, the campus postal service lost their marriage license. They originally transferred from Texas A&M, so some of the staff members treated them like they were heathens (or otherwise non-believers), despite the fact that they were believers. They were held to a much stricter code here than if they were living in their own homes, & treated more like kids than the adults they are. It was also stricter than Lubbock Christian University, where I had my college experience. (For "faith purposes", Harding comes across as one of the more "legalistic" of the Christian colleges & universities throughout America.)

My sister also had to jump thru a lot of hoops with the academic advisors, to make sure that her classes all transferred & she received credit. She was glad that she only had to spend that year (& graduate in July), & no more! (She was just "following" her husband, since Harding was the physical therapy program that accepted him.)

My brother-in-law was also overjoyed that he didn't need to spend more than 3 years for his degree! He was also on his own to find his clinical rotations during the last half of his program. (I went to Texas Tech for pharmacy school, & they had a specific staff member who was in charge of coordinating clinical rotations. Maybe Harding's PT [&/or pharmacy school, etc] will look into that for future classes.)

For other personal reasons, I was glad to know that Harding also had a pharmacy school, as well as a physical therapy program. And I'm also glad to know they have sought ways to improve, so they can reach more people.

review.author: Kaiden C.
review.description: I got my license in a week with Frost. I used to be very nervous when driving and I was really worried about driving in general. Jim Wells was an excellent instructor and taught me so much; I ended up passing my drivers license test with a 98! It was so much fun seeing my improvement, as well as learning and asking questions to better myself as a new driver. I couldn't be happier with my experience with Frost.

review.author: Kristal C.
review.description: Frost is a great driving school. Their knowledge and thoroughness made them the best tool for our child. The driving lessons gave her the confidence and skills she needed. Also being able to do our DPS testing there was the invaluable. The office staff is friendly and very helpful. I can't say enough things about the staff and the services.

review.author: Rachel M.
review.description: My son went to take his drive test today, his instructor was so calm and reassuring, he didn't bring any stress to the situation, only ease. I'm so grateful for this place, and will recommend to everyone I know.

review.author: Lauren K.
review.description: Cedar Park location: Coach Andrew Frost is an awesome person to do your driving test with  \nHe was pleasant to chat with and right on time. If you're in the Austin/cedar park area and need to take a driving test, call him because he's your man.

review.author: Daniel H.
review.description: My sister-in-laws experience.\nDONT GO TO FROST DRIVING SCHOOL IN BELTON! For those that know me...I am an easy going person, that always has a positive out look on people.  But my KID WAS PUBLICLY SHAMED AND HURT IN FRONT OF PEERS TODAY. \nMy daughter was taking her driving hours at FROST,  we did parent taught for the first half, but wanted to get extra hours with an instructor so she would feel more comfortable behind the wheel, because my daughter was in a accident as passenger when she was 14 and almost lost her leg, she was hospitalized for over a month with multiple surgeries and had to finish out her school year at home.   When Elexis started her first hours,  I asked the instructor (Pam) how Elexis did and she said "good'.  A few driving hours later,  I get a call that Elexis had an accident in the drivers education car with Pam in the passenger seat.   The cops were at the scene and I was told that Elexis had ran a two way stop sign ( a white truck was parked in front of the sign), and the other car "t-boned" the front passenger wheel base.  My kid was extremely upset for days not wanting to ever drive again.   I noticed that instead of the instructor using this as a teaching tool, Pam was blaming ALL the fault on Elexis!   When I got home, I called the driving school to speak to the owner, the owner called me back and I explained to him how I did not like how Pam was blaming and belittling my daughter in front of the police officer.  Pam is the instructor and "accidents" happen.  Really...did Pam not see the stop sign either???  Did Pam have a break pad to use??  After the nice conversation it was agreed that Elexis would finish her hours with a different instructor.  After the completion of Elexis hours we waited to get Elexis more driving time on the home front, and went today July 10, 2017 to book the driving test,   Elexis and I walked into the driving school to register for the test slot at 1:40pm.  I looked back and saw Pam sitting at a table with other students.   When we sat down I heard Pam say very loudly " IS SHE TESTING TODAY'?  The lady behind the desk nodded her head yes.  I turned around and I gave Pam the "thumbs up" with a smile and told her "Lexi is ready!  Lexi is going to pass.  We have been practicing," with a nice genuine smile.  I noticed that Pam was glaring at me and Elexis with a rude look on her face.   Pam stood up and said with people in the lobby "YEA IF NO ONE IS IN THE CAR" directly to me and my teenager.  The receptionist looked at us and started to apologize for what was just said to us in front of a lobby full of her peers.   Elexis stood up and walked out the door not saying a word.  I sat there and finished the paperwork so upset tears were rolling down my face.  Again the receptionist was apologizing to me for what the instructor Pam had said.  I went to check on Elexis in the truck.  My teenager was crying her eyes out saying that she did not want to take her test anymore she was embarrassed and could not believe that adults acted this way.  I tried to calm her down the best I could.  NEXT, I went back into FROST driving school and asked the instructor Pam, "why did you say that to us?, you have no idea what my child has been though what she has had to endure to get here!  You should be ashamed of your self! You are a teacher, and instructor, this is not how you act!  Pam proceeded to be RUDE, MEAN, AND UNPROFESSIONAL!  Pam, expressed to me that I should be ashamed of myself as a parent to put my daughter behind the wheel,  Pam also stated that Elexis can not feel with her foot ( WHICH IS NOT TRUE!!)  JUST BECAUSE MY TEENAGER HAS A PARTIAL DISABILITY WITH RANGE OF MOTION, AND YOU THE DRIVING INSTRUCTOR INSTEAD OF LIFTING UP MY CHILD, AND TEACHING MY CHILD.  PAM COMPLETELY ACTED UNPROFESSIONAL AND PUBLICLY SHAMED MY CHILD.  THIS INSTRUCTOR NEEDS TO LOOSE HER LICENSE FOR WHAT SHE HAS DONE.  I ALSO HAVE PROOF FROM OTHER STUDENTS THAT SHE SPEAKS BAD OF OTHER STUDENT DRIVERS TO HER STUDENTS DURING BEHIND THE WHEEL INSTRUCTION.

review.author: Tim B.
review.description: We thought the Pflugerville Mega-center still did the walk-in driver test, but found out the hard way (got there at 5am, no line?  Oh no!) they only accept appointments now.  Next available was over a month out.  We called Coach Frost and amazingly, he was able to get us in that evening.  My daughter did great, passed her test, and coach Frost was a pleasure to deal with.  We met in Cedar Park across from ACC in the Lakehills Freewill Baptist Church parking lot.  Coach sets up the parallel parking cones there, and once that step is done, he takes the driver out to drive around some of the neighborhoods.  We were in and out within 30 minutes.  The best!!!

review.author: Jason B.
review.description: Excellent instruction from Frost Driving School has helped my daughter become a safer driver.

review.author: Peggy A.
review.description: I just returned from Kevin's "Fall Photography Fundamentals Workshop" and it is the best class I have ever taken, and I have taken a lot.  He was so prepared to the point he provided the class with binders that included all of the information he was showing on the screen.  All we had to do was make a few notes if we wanted which allowed us to pay attention to what he was showing and saying.  He is extremely patient and goes out of his way to be sure every student understands what he is saying.  I don't care how long you've been photographing, I'm pretty sure you'll learn something new.  If you're a beginner this is definitely the class to be in.  I cannot recommend his classes enough.  They are not overpriced and you get a lot of bang for your buck.

review.author: Edgar S.
review.description: So my review is for his class not his actual work. I signed up for his basic course after thinking that I probably need to pick up a hobby to fill my time during retirement. From day 1, Kevin was very responsive and sent reminders about locations and class days. He is an amazing teacher that used stories and analogies to get his points across. After so many courses in the military, I didn't know how to react when faced with an instructor that genuinely cares about teaching and just wants the world to enjoy the beauty of photography. I enjoyed every session and plan on signing up for another class with him to learn about lighting. as far as pricing, i dont know what the normal price points are for these types of classes. I found him on yelp and I was very happy with my ROI.

review.author: Jonathan L.
review.description:
Had a great experience getting my headshot done with Kevin!

He was quick in responding when I inquired about getting a professional headshot for work. After my initial call, he had sent a form to get my appointment booked for the next weekday. 

I arrived about 15-20 minutes earlier than my expected appointment and never brought it up, nor did he make me wait. He also offered to wear a mask if I felt more comfortable and offered me a bottled water. I never felt rushed, and he made it clear he could take as many photos as I'd like until I was satisfied. 

Highly recommend.

review.author: Allan C.
review.description: Kevin did a great job for my Executive Photo. Easy and fun to work with. Very talented and open to listening to what the client wants. Caught him on a good day and he was able to turn the photos around very quickly. Very reasonable price.

review.author: Tiffany M.
review.description: Such a great experience! We loved our stops and the owners were the best! Our tour guide was so informative and so nice! We had so much fun!!

review.author: Deanna B.
review.description:
We decided to take a Waco Wine Tour and visit Magnolia for my friend's bachlorette party. Yes it was a a fun weekend, and yes I remember everything!

With the Waco Wine Tour you get to stop at three wineries and sample about 5-6 samples at each winery. There is also a stop at a vineyard (and unfortunately we didn't go at the right season), but you get to see where all the vines and grapes grow, as well as have a delicious snack from a nearby market!

I found some great wine I liked and our tour guide Joey was amazing! Our guide was friendly, knowledgeable, patient, and answered every random question we could think of. He let us have alone time, giving us the right amount or privacy, but was always engaging and positive when we wanted to include him in girl time. 

I'm so glad I got this as my first wine tour experience, and if I'm ever in the area, I will have to come back and take the tour again... as well as buy some delicious wine!

review.author: Molly S.
review.description: We had the most amazing time on the Waco Wine Tours bus! Accommodating, easy, and fun! Valley Mills Vineyard was our favorite, but all of the stops and wine was delicious! Staff was knowledgeable, driver was so great, and everything was always on time! This is the perfect type of excursion to add to a Waco weekend!

review.author: M M.
review.description: Joey was awesome!!! All three wineries were great but the tour at Valley Mills was top notch. We learned a lot and had a great time!

review.author: Krysta R.
review.description: We had a bachelorette party book a wine tour. Joey was awesome! He made the trip fun and gave us a bunch of neat history. The vineyards are so pretty and can not wait to see them grow! He even came back to our destination to deliver lost items left on the bus. Highly recommend this company for your tour!

review.author: Tony L.
review.description: Took the Waco Wine Tour over the weekend.  We were greeted by Joey our tour guide and driver of the tour shuttle.  Our tour included wine tastings at three wineries and a nice outdoor lunch stop at Valley Mills Winery surrounded by their grape fields.  Joey is a very personable and knowledgeable on all aspects of the wine making process.  The tour lasted for almost four hours.  I would highly recommend this wine tour to anyone wanting to learn and taste central Texas growing wine community.

review.author: Chelsi B.
review.description: I went to Katy's childbirth education class today and it's very informative! I enjoyed listening and watching the videos that she presented, it was well organized and she knows what she is talking about! She has several handouts you can take home with information you can discuss with your doctor, and she goes over the ins and outs of labor, delivery and the golden hour. I highly recommend Katy!

review.author: Stephanie E.
review.description: Katy is passionate about all things related to pregnancy, childbirth and postpartum care. She is extremely knowledgeable and has experience not only with her five children, but with many happy clients she has faithfully served. Katy's strongest quality is her ability to hold strong personal beliefs based on her experience and education, and yet be a caring professional in how she listens to her clients and supports their decisions- no matter what.  You won't be disappointed if you choose her as your doula. You'll have someone there completely for YOU, who loves and cares as if it were her own birth experience. I highly recommend CTB!

review.author: Giovanny D.
review.description: Well Andy and Aron are sick, and infected me with the need for speed. The rally experience was a blast. We got  do three solo laps and by the end of them you think you're actually doing well and flying through the course.  Then you get to sit passenger as one of the instructors flys through the course and you realize how slow you have been driving. I was doing school zone speeds when they're doing highway speeds.\n\nThis was a great experience. I have to do classes now cause I couldn't get enough

review.author: Conrad D.
review.description: I took advantage of the discount they were offering for private instruction. Andy and Mikey were great instructors. Also got to meet Rob and Dave also. I have nothing but positive things to say about the experience. I would recommend bringing gloves regardless of how hot (or not). \n\nI will definitely be back.

review.author: Eric B.
review.description:
Just finished a two-day course here this past weekend. Perhaps the most bang-for-your-buck fun I've had anywhere. Dave, Rob and the rest of the instructors make the experience totally fun, enjoyable, and non-intimidating. It seems like an overwhelming amount of information to take on in such a short amount of time (and honestly they will be the first ones to tell you that it is), but the instructors are all super patient and fun and their attitude makes you want to just keep trying and trying again. It's like being told the way you know how to drive a car is completely wrong and you need to re-learn everything all at once...but it's a total blast while you're doing it. 

And honestly, even with all the great fun you'll have throwing around rally cars in the dirt, the best part for me what just the sense of camaraderie and community the people at RR have built there. I would honestly be just as happy going down there to hang out and talk with all the great guys and just chill out. The culture is so fun and inviting. 

Yes it's a little pricey, but it's totally worth saving up for the experience. (They do a great job on their site of explaining why it's worth it...and it is). I totally want to do it again and try some of their other class offerings sometime...but also just to spend time with a great group of people (and dogs!)

Just remember though...the tomatoes are store-bought. :)

review.author: Gus H.
review.description: We are SO lucky to have a Rally School here in Austin and even better, one that is run by such a great team. This crew shows how the automotive racing scene should be done. Fun, energetic, ego-free, and safe. We have been to the ranch a few times now and we have an absolute blast each time! Book a corporate party and you will not regret it!

review.author: Emily L.
review.description: My husband and I did the Rally Experience where you get to drive 3 laps in one of their rally cars (Subaru WRX) and then go on a hot lap with one of the instructors. It was a BLAST! Neither of us have any racing or rally driving experience, but my husband loves Subarus and had heard this was a cool experience so figured why not try it out. There were 6 of us in our session and none of us had any experience with rally driving. The instructors were super chill and made everyone feel very comfortable. They take you around a lap first before you drive yourself. I drove the automatic car since I hadn't driven a manual in 15+ years, but one of the instructors patiently (re-)taught me how to use the manual on the fly and I got to try a lap in that car as well, which was definitely a confidence booster! \n\nThe laps you drive are super fun, but the real fun is doing the hot lap with one of the instructors. Holy hell, that was one of the most fun, adrenaline packed experiences I've ever had!! They definitely make you feel like you can become a rally driver in no time!! Would 100% recommend this!!!

review.author: Daniel C.
review.description: My groomsmen and I went here to kick off the first day of our trip. It was an awesome experience from beginning to end. I sent a pretty open-ended email a few weeks prior saying what we were looking for, and Dave got back to me quickly w/ a perfect proposal, combining some driving and ride-along in UTVs. Very easy payment system too. When one of the guys wasn't going to be able to make it, RR was very flexible on the pricing change. Once we were there, they walked us through a straightforward training/guidelines, and cut us loose. The UTVs take some getting used to but felt really safe on the track and in the woods. The ride-along is insane (and inspiring)... At the end of the few hours we hung out with their dogs with some great memories and pictures.

review.author: Dr. Dan B.
review.description:
Just a burn-your-pants-off good time!  

Dave and his crew of skilled instructors bring tons of real-life racing experience to a racing school environment, and even though I've never raced cars before, they made the learning experience a total blast from start to finish.  

I did the 1-day class, and I really wish I'd done at least 2 days with them -- it was that good.

But in one day I got tons of seat time learning and mastering the essential skills of off-road racing, with patient, experienced instructors in the seat next to me, in at least 5 different cars.  Our class of 7 people had zero experience racing before, and we were all drifting through turns, flooring it through corners, power braking and kicking up rooster tails of dirt with huge grins plastered our faces the whole time!

Highly recommend this incredibly professional team of racing teachers, who really stick with you to make sure you learn the skills and have a complete blast while you're doing it.  I'll definitely be going back for more of this killer experience :)

review.author: Colt E.
review.description: These guys are awesome! They made our day a hell of an experience: making sure we had fun, were well fed, and most of all practicing extreme patience with us. Can't say enough how they tailor the experience to you and all skill levels are welcome. Hope I get to come back soon!

review.author: Dick A.
review.description: We visited the Rally Ready team on Friday night to shoot some Gremlins on the go.  Dave, Cleo, and Jordan made it a wonderful experience!  Jordan wheeled us around on the extreme off road adventure and it was a WOW!  This team is fantastic and we will hold some more team building events with them!  WAY COOL!  Thank you again Dave, Cleo, and Jordan!

review.author: Brandi M.
review.description: So much fun!!! Dave and crew were wonderful!! Went this past weekend and did the 1/2 day program. Instructors teaching the class were very encouraging and motivational and really made it fun!!! If you enjoy driving cars this is perfect and such a hidden gem in the Austin area.

review.author: Deanna R.
review.description: My husband Carl and I took a day class with Dave when we were in TX in October.  We had SO much fun!  Dave is a great teacher - very patient, calm and gives clear, easy to understand instructions - but is also a great person.  At the start of the day we knew what left foot breaking was and had seen videos showing fancy footwork by the professionals, but we had no hopes of really being able to do it very well in such a short time.  But at the end of the day when we put into action all the skills we had just learned on the mini-rally course at the Ranch, we actually DID it!  Dave fed us the co-driver instructions and it made sense!  Pikes Peak, here we come!  Thanks again Dave, we had an amazing time!

review.author: Jason M.
review.description: Went to work with Dave and the shredding crew for a 3 day course with 6 friends last weekend and it was amazing! At the start he demo'd some driving and all of us were like 'ummm...there is no way we will be doing that', but by the end of the first day we were sliding around and having a blast no problem!  We were abusing those cars and tearing them apart but they were fixing them as fast as we were ripping off tires and bumpers. It was DIRTY and educational and most importantly super damn good times. My only complaint was the weather came in hard and rained out our 3rd day, but Dave said, 'well now you all got a day credit so come back and we'll have even more courses for you guys to shred.' He then took us off-roading  in his jeep on a tour of his acres then launched us over a jump, (chainsaws and all) for his entertainment as much as ours. :) Needless to say, we will all be returning to Austin.

review.author: Michele C.
review.description: We have boy girl twins and we're dreading the thought of having to train them together as they are like a married couple that has been together a long time. So we got the idea of sending them to a driving school and we spent the next several months trying to find something super cool for them, have a ton of fun, and safely learn to truly drive a car in extreme situations. We searched high and low and contacted numerous places. We ultimately decided on Ralky Ready after all our research. Dave answered all our calls and questions and he was by far the easiest to work with. So we booked hotels and flights and decided to take the leap. Boy did Rally Ready hit the ball out of the park we could not have been more pleased. Dave and his Team exceeded our expectations and that of my kids by a mile. They had so much fun, drove for two straight days and have not been able to stop talking about the experience.  The things they learned most drivers on the road will never learn, taking a car to the edge of its performance envelope than learning with expert instruction how to recover that vehicle back onto the course can only be done in a facility like this. You could just see their confidence soar from the first day to the next.  What was so impressive about the place was the ease that the instructors moved back and forth between novice drivers such as my kids and professional drivers coming to the facility to all get better.  Having that level of comfort and trust with your instructor makes the learning that much more fun and meaningful.  Facilities were great and would recommend this to anyone at any level.  Thank you again Dave and please extend a double thumbs up to your entire crew.

review.author: Mike R.
review.description: Easy to work with.  Great online scheduling.  Have only used for transfers, but so much better than a gun store upset you didn't buy from them.\n\nReportedly a fantastic gunsmith too.

review.author: Cam V.
review.description: Used Tim for FFL service he was quick to respond to any questions I had and very personable will be recommending him to family and friends

review.author: Michael V.
review.description: I recently had Colonel Smith install some Truglo tfx sights on an M and P Shield. I found him to be very personable, extremely knowledgeable,  and very affordable.  The work he did was outstanding.  Tested at the range today and the sights are solid and dead on. I will definitely take any firearm work I need directly to Colonel Smith. Highly recommend his work and his promptness!

review.author: John E.
review.description: Would not respond to a problem with his initial service. I was forced to seek remedy from someone else.

review.author: Keegan L.
review.description: I want to first start this off by saying how smooth, and precise Tim is with his work. This was my first time EVER going to a gunsmith, and it went really well thanks to TIM! What makes this even better, is that he's not a 20 year old who graduated YOUTUBE university! He's a reliable man who has gone through REAL training to do what he does today. I'm grateful we still have people who are passionate about the SAFETY of guns and not how fast the money comes! Thanks Tim!

review.author: Jonathan F.
review.description: Extremely helpful, courteous and knowledgeable. I had an issue with my rifle, he had it sorted out very quickly and I was happy.

review.author: Randall R.
review.description: I have an old 12 gauge, single shot , hammer action Nitro King with a broken shell ejector. Tim was able to find a close fit made by another company; he was able to do a little machine work for a perfect fit on my Nitro King; he also shimmed the joint where the barrel breaks down to snug the barrel to the magazine that had worn from use elimination gas blowback. A real gunsmith...not just a remove and replace technician.

review.author: Chris X.
review.description: I have used Tim's services for both a FFL transfer and a sight replacement.  He is knowledgeable, professional, prompt and friendly.  I would highly recommend him.

review.author: david t.
review.description: Tim has provided excellent service in both receiving FFL purchases for me and in cleaning and servicing 2 old rifles and my Granddad's old shotgun. I bought 2 pistols and 1 rifle online and had them shipped to Tim. He inspected them and emailed me as soon as they arrived. Scheduling a pickup through his website is super easy.  I dropped my old guns for him to clean and service and it took a little while for him to work on them. He was extremely busy over the holidays, but it was worth the wait.  I have an old WWII Enfield rifle with a barrel that WAS caked with copper from shooting 50 years ago. Tim got it sparkling clean like brand new. Reasonable prices too. I highly recommend Tim Smith Gunsmith for all your gun needs in the Austin/Georgetown area. Plus he's a super nice guy.

review.author: Brandi L.
review.description: I'm absolutely THRILLED with Mathnasium of Champaign! My daughter is a 3rd grader, was testing at the first grade level in math, and scored in the 7th percentile on Aimsweb scores in August 2020. Recently, her fall Aimsweb scores were sent to me and she tested in the 24th percentile and her 9 week grade for math at her school was an A-. As a special education teacher, I was ecstatic to see this improvement! I would HIGHLY recommend Mathnasium to any student who is struggling with math!

review.author: Jamie R.
review.description: My daughter went to Mathnasium for 6 months. She has improved not only in her skills, but in her attitude and confidence towards math. She enjoyed going to her sessions each week, challenging herself and setting her own goals for getting through her cards. I would highly recommend Mathnasium to anyone who struggles with math!

review.author: Jennifer C.
review.description: We are currently sending our children to school at First Baptist.  \n\nI have been impressed with every teacher my children have had since pre-school, until currently (2nd & 3rd grade).  If my child has struggled with something the teacher has always communicated with me and been willing to spend extra time with them.

review.author: Chloe H.
review.description: I have been attending this school since second grade and I have loved almost every minute of it. There were a few times when there were some issues but mostly every year has been awesome.

review.author: Careth S.
review.description: Safe, close knit environment with small class sizes and advanced far above public elementary school. God centered and cares about each child as an individual.

review.author: Micki O.
review.description:
My child attended this school through second grade. The school has a few very well meaning teacher. However,  we found it to be severely lacking academically.  He finished 2nd grade unable to do basic subtraction.  When I asked for an evaluation for special services through the local public school district, First Baptist didn't really cooperate. When it came time for the meeting to discuss results, the principal hid in his office and sent a "proxy" who didn't do anything but sit with his head down the entire time. No one was interested in getting him the help he needed.  I was at a loss as to what to do. At the end of the year his standardized testing results came back below average in every area and in the lower 10-15% nationally.  Thankfully I found a school willing to work to catch him up. Within 2 years he was performing in the 75-90% on his standardized testing, which tells me my child wasn't to biggest component in his learning issue there.

Religiously he received a so - so education.  I know others have reviewed with huge marks for the religious aspect, but if your instruction doesn't match how things play out in real life it's useless.

Lastly, their sports crowds tend to show very poor sportsmanship. I know that's hard to believe,  given what the other reviews boast, but from the outside looking in,  their behavior at sporting events ( in my experience) has been in poor taste.

review.author: Lydia C.
review.description: My son goes to the First Baptist School since he was 3 years old. The school is amazing. I will strongly recommend this school to everybody. Teaching your kids what's right and wrong, discipline, manners, gods word etc, etc you name it. This is what our kids need to know, learn in the world we live right now. We are so busy with work and others that sometimes we don't have time to teach our kids but this school teach them. Keep up the good work First Baptist School.

review.author: Dawn L.
review.description: If you want a school that teaches your kids to love God and country, to respect themselves and others and to live their lives with honor and dignity, then this is the place for your kids.  Your children will not only learn the three "R's" but they will also learn how to live life in such a way that they make the world a better place just by their having been in it.

review.author: Jerry V.
review.description:
While it's not as hard as the Armory to figure out, some rooms on the third floor are quite oddly positioned. There's a pretty neat atrium/courtyard in the middle section which has a few couches and a lounge-type area on the ground floor. There's a few vending machine's in the ground floor lounge area as well. 

The computer lab is pretty awesome. It has both mac and pc's which is a rarity for university computer labs and all the cpu's are apple's so its fast and everything.

Now the main reason I'm writing this is because of the bathroom in the ground floor by the vending machines. I can't speak for the girls one but the boys one absolutely smells horrendous. I've smelled some nasty bathrooms in my lifetime and I could honestly say that there would be no difference in the fragrance of the restroom if I decided to take a piss on the floor instead of the urinal... I really hope someone see's this and tries to do whatever's necessary because I hate having to go upstairs when I'm in the computer lab.

review.author: Spencer S.
review.description:
As Jerry V. has written about the English Building, "some rooms on the third floor are quite oddly positioned." A lot of people who work in the building are oddly positioned as well, but what does that have to do with the building itself?

There is so much charm, I think, in the English building. It's full of things like little offices with huge fireplaces and gigantic offices with no heat. Wood floors wobble and creak; light filters into the atrium at all hours of the day. Modern conveniences such as wireless internet is strong in certain parts of the building and completely absent in other places. 

All you have to do is take a look at the new Lincoln Hall to see what it's like to lose all the charm of a place like the English Building.

review.author: Keith S.
review.description:
My family is not Catholic, however our son attends St. Paul.  The staff, teachers and administration are all wonderful to deal with.

Not coming from that church, we are very happy with how accepting everyone is.

I would suggest you visit, you will be sold.

address.streetAddress: 1401 W Green St\n324 Illini Union, M/C 384

name: University of Illinois Student Legal Services
Ven Te Chow Hydrosystems Lab @ The University of Illinois

review.author: Mauricio P.
review.description:
The Ven Te Chow Hydrosystems Lab is one of the leading institutes of hydrology and hydraulics. Home of one of the biggest and more active hydraulics lab provides basic and apply research in areas such as river and  coastal morphodynamics, sediment dynamics, enviromental hydraulics between many others... 

For more information go to

http://vtchl.uiuc.edu/

review.author: Rahul G.
review.description:
I hated UIUC with a passion, however, as time has passed, I've begun to realize that UIUC made me what I am today. It gave me all the necessary tools to succeed. It is truly my Alma Mater.

I was an international undergraduate student at UIUC, which has a great support system for international students. We had special counselors and staff to help us get adjusted to the American way of life. 

I majored in electrical engineering and minored in chemistry, and took my stay here extremely seriously. The fact that my family was paying three times the fees local students pay, failure wasn't an option for me. I never partied during my stay here. 

My review is only concerning the College of Engineering.

UIUC has very high standards. Every ECE course is like an honors course. No matter how impressive your ACT or SAT scores are or how smart you think you are, there will always be someone better than you are at UIUC. I learned this the hard way. Don't despair; befriend those people and study with them. They'll help you survive.

Our ECE department is one of the best in the country; our instructors are the very best in the industry and graduates of top schools - whether local or international. For example, many of my professors and TAs were graduates of the Indian Institute of Technology - considered one of the best institution and most selective in the world. They seemed weird and aloof at times, but they were very approachable and were always available for additional help.

I had professors who were graduates of MIT, Yale and CalTech.

The university also hosted various international speakers of high caliber - like Bill Gates and Ravi Zacharias. It was great to see these men in person and hear them speak.

UIUC also had great worship nights for Christians.

The university also hosted various international events like Diwali nights and Indian dance competitions.

Here are five tips for surviving the College of Engineering:

1. Get into a study group with people who are smarter than you. This will help you work in a team.
2. Do your homework - yourself. Only get help if you get stuck.
3. Do the old exams in your study group.
4. Sleep at night.
5. In additional to your studies, do an extra project or thesis in order to make your resume more impressive.

After four years of broken hearts, failed exams, and sleepless nights, I successfully graduated from ECE. I can proudly say that I studied with the brightest people in the world. I actually miss those days and can think of so many things I would have done differently if given a second chance.

Rahul G (BSEE)

review.author: Karen L.
review.description: Alumni - I returned for Homecoming and almost didn't recognize the campus. What was once an incredibly beautiful campus with gorgeous old buildings and ivy has been taken over at every corner with high rises. In walking around, we saw a high-rise right next to a beautiful fraternity. The lawns are no longer sprawling. The bells of Altgeld are no longer playing. The beauty is gone. Enrollment has almost doubled since I attended and it has become apparent that the University is concerned more about $ than excellence and tradition. I really think the U of I spirit is disappearing. My sense is that in future years, alumni support will decrease.

review.author: Naomi O.
review.description: This University is really cool！!！ The building is like a Europian！！！！\nThere are many place to eat Asian food around here, too！！！

review.author: Ryan C.
review.description: This is a good campus with solid science being done.  A recent DoE grant was received helping them to continue their success in a multidisciplinary approach to sustainable bio-based energy and chemicals.  However, if you are anti-GMO you might not like the work that is being done. \n\nWhat did I learn today?  You can force plant pathways to store oils in their stems.

review.author: Ricky P.
review.description: One of the best places in the world for you to get a CS degree

review.author: Angela 0.
review.description: CS suckssss, do not come here for CS. YOu're in the middle of a cornfield and you're dyingggggg. Also they dont care about uuuuuu. I just want to have funn and not dream in 0's and 1's. Also what the HECK are these cohort registration restrictions, like bro, i just want to at least be interested in the classes im getting fucked in the ass by

review.author: Naomi K.
review.description:
Was just stopping by to briefly walk around the quad, check out the Lincoln center and admire the revamped alma mater (was taken down for repolishing). We visit every few years to check out the old stomping grounds and see what had changed. 
Amidst all the financial scandals, the Lincoln theater does look quite impressive. Classes were in session so we couldn't see be main theater but the hall was quite nice. The little courtyards house the bricks bearing names of the donations. I was expecting a large wall with hundreds of donors but it looked a little sad seeing so few bricks engraved. I suspect they are hoping for the coming years to add to it, as the alumni list grows but from the looks for it, most of it was very old alumni and nothing newer than the class of 2007. 
Some of the bricks looked unsteady on the bumpy ground. Hopefully no ones brick breaks. 
The quad looked dead in the freezing cold mid-April winter with empty trees but green grass. 
The foreign language building looked cool with a indoor courtyard, albeit an older building.
The bell tower in the mathematics building was unfortunately closed. We missed the narrow window of 12:30-1 pm, for a tour. 
Parking was challenging even just to find a metered spot. 
The area around has grown quite a bit with big high rise apartments and a new Marriot (TownePlace suites) on Green and new restaurants, but all catered toward the college student.

review.author: David C.
review.description:
I'm writing this review as a UIUC graduate. I attended 2008-2012 and I received an undergraduate degree in biology. 

Positives:

-The campus is really beautiful and generally visually appealing. The architecture is fantastic. As you walk around campus, it feels quintessential. It's especially college-looking in the fall. (You know, like all the brochures that get sent out.)

-You are only required to live on campus freshmen year. This means I lived in an apartment off campus for three of my four years. It's much cheaper than on-campus housing with a meal plan. 

-You'll meet some of your best friends for life here. It's the Midwest. People are friendly. If you're from Illinois, I can guarantee that a chunk of your high school graduating class will end up here. When you meet someone, chances are you have some mutual friends or other connections. It's a small world for such a big school. 

-We host some pretty epic events here. Like Unofficial. I don't think I need to say anything more about that. 

-Your education is whatever you make of it. Some people go to every class, sit in the front row, study like crazy, revise papers, see professors during office hours, do undergrad research, etc. Other people slide by and only go to class when there's an exam. It is possible to get an A in a class you have never attended (obviously, it's only true of certain classes in certain disciplines). 

-We're a big school, so we get a lot more resources than smaller schools. 

-If you stay in IL after graduating, there are a lot of networking opportunities. Chicago is filled with U of I grads and many of them are keen on hiring other alumni. 

-There are tons of clubs, intramurals, and other student-led organizations to keep you busy here if you're so inclined. 

Negatives:

-This school is expensive. I graduated almost three years ago and I'm still swimming in debt. A lot of people have the impression that you'll save money by choosing to go to a public state school. It's really sobering to see the kind of debt I have even as an in-state student. If I had known this my senior year in high school, I would have done two years at community college and transferred instead to save money. 

-Greek life can somewhat overwhelm the social scene at times. To give you an idea, I was labeled as "unaffiliated" or as a "GDI" for not choosing to join a frat. If you want to go Greek, though, this would probably go as a positive.  

-Urbana/Champaign has nothing going for it except for the university. Everything in the area caters to college students. There are perks to this, but sometimes you just want to be near a city to go out and DO things. No wonder drinking is so big here. Sometimes there isn't much else to do. 

-A lot of lab/research opportunities are for graduate students only.

review.author: Robert G.
review.description:
Getting right to the point ...

Pros:  academically excellent, should be considered a Public Ivy, competitiveness brings out the best in you, once you scrape past the Greeks there are some intelligent individualistic students, a beautiful Quad, the Student Union, nice "down home" townies, students from rural towns / St Louis metro / Indy metro / out of state / out of the country are cool, cheap living, and lots of good eats on Green Street ... and actually all around "Chambana."

Cons:  middle of nowhere, oppressive location, too far from a major city for road tripping and being able to manage a heavy academic workload, obnoxious Greeks, crappy weather most of the academic year (but the few weeks of peak color are beautiful), many North Shore students, Chicago meat heads, alcohol and sleazy places to drink it are many people's "raison d'etre," and occasional faculty members with their heads so far up their tenured asses that they aren't interested in teaching or making themselves accessible 

I am writing this review for the benefit of potential undergraduates from a distant out of state location and potential grad students as well.  For the undergrads, one review voiced that if you fall outside of traditional college demographics, this is NOT a fun place to go to school.  I could easily see that.  For graduate students, it isn't as diverse as one might expect of such a highly reputed school. The actual diversity is there, but the factions don't mix.  There is a very state-centric attitude and if you don't come from Chicagoland and don't plan to settle in Chicagoland upon finishing, "those people," the bulk of U of I, can be somewhat dismissive.  Similarly, the alumni links are more tailgate worthy than they are for networking.  

Bottom line:  U of I can be enticing for its top of the heap rankings in engineering and accounting, among other fields, but it's not like all the available slots in those fields are only reserved for U of I grads.  If you are from Illinois and know "the lay of the land" then, sure, do take advantage of this bargain in public education, relatively speaking.  However, you can also find and consider other great public universities to put on your shopping list if from out of the region.

review.author: Peter G.
review.description:
Disclaimer: This review is biased by extreme nostalgia.

Illinois is a stellar university, with top-ranked programs in engineering, chemistry, accountancy, and physics. Despite its high scholarship, the campus, overall, has a refreshingly unassuming tone. No pretension here.

The student body at this public university is massive, and as such you'll find a range of kids. At the time of this writing, the running count of registered student organizations (RSOs) topped 800! The Urbana-Champaign Hip Hop Congress may be one of my favorites. Each year they put on Hip Hop Awareness Week, which introduces the campus to the origins and history of the hip hop movement.

It would be difficult to capture the world that is Illinois in a Yelp review. But if you're ever in town during the semester, spend some time in the Illini (Student) Union to get an idea of what this place is all about.

review.author: Sherwin C.
review.description: One of the best research institutions in the world with many high ranking programs.

review.author: Shawn W.
review.description:
UIUC is a damn good college. The engineering is world-class, we're the best party school according to some survey, we do a lot of research, all that stuff. It's a state school so it's not too expensive if you're an Illinoisan, which is a decent reparation for growing up in the least interesting region in the States.

I got my bachelor's in CS here 2012-2016 and I can safely say that UIUC prepared me for a great career. For the most part, my classes were well-taught, gave me lots of valuable knowledge, and at least with the schedule I chose, I very rarely felt excessively stressed out. I had a full-time job offer (at Yelp!) months before I graduated, and all my other engineering friends were in the same boat. There are tons of career fairs here each semester and companies love to recruit from UIUC, so as long as you make an effort you have a very good chance of landing a full-time offer before graduation. Some of my friends had a full-time offer at the beginning of their senior years and another had one after he finished his sophomore year. Rest assured, if you're a fantastic student and do a good job of putting yourself out there, you will be employed.

Some of the classes and professors I've had were excellent. Special shoutouts to Eric Snodgrass of ATMS 120 fame, Jon Solomon in CLCV, and the entire Astronomy department. Of course I've had some professors who weren't very good, but I'd say that on the whole, the average UIUC professor is well above average. They're all very bright and qualified, but some just aren't as good at teaching as others. But not everyone can be perfect, right?

Outside of academics, there's a decent amount to do. There are lots of clubs, which you can (and 100% should) check out on Quad Day at the beginning of each year. There are a ton of bars and restaurants in the area, and you're especially in luck if you like Chinese food. The age to enter bars is only 19, so even sophomores can have the true college experience (even though they can't legally drink). The Canopy Club on the East side of campus has had some reasonably big-name bands like the Chainsmokers, Madeon, and Porter Robinson, so keep an eye on who's coming next. There are some movie theaters nearby, a mall, and lots of Illini sports to watch, even if you don't like watching your football team suck for the umteenth year in a row. There are also nature trails nearby if you're into biking or jogging, though there isn't much in the way of scenery. Different school departments have events regularly, too. There are lots of plays and concerts in Krannert, there's the annual Engineering Open House, and the Astronomy department regularly opens up the old observatory on the south side of the Quad on clear nights for anyone to stargaze.

Unfortunately, it's located in the middle of scenic nowhere, so no matter where you lived before coming here, you probably have to drive at least a couple hours to go home (or anywhere worth going, like Chicago or STL). Be prepared to stay close to campus all four years. Oh yeah, and the weather is pretty bad. It gets up into the 90s in the summer, drops down into the single-digits and negatives in the winter with a yearly paralyzing blizzard. There isn't much of a spring or fall. I also recently learned about "corn sweat", which is a phenomenon wherein the massive amounts of corn in Central Illinois siphon water out of the ground and directly into the atmosphere, making some days unbearably humid in addition to their high temperatures. So be ready for that.

So, yeah. Great school. Would go again.

review.author: Hank C.
review.description:
Great school for engineering, certainly strong in electrical engineering and food science/ chemical engineering.

Campus is very spread out. If you don't drive around (few do due to the lack of parking, surprisingly), you usually will jog from point to point or rollerblade, bike or try to keep classes close together.  Like most of the Midwest schools, there's plenty of grass and few trees... but that's okay, you don't expect anything other than fields of corn when you come to Illinois, right? Not forests.

Students and staff are generally friendly to visitors, but few people like the very cold, very snowy/icy winters.

*edit: As I was asked: I was only a visitor here, not a student.

review.author: Richard B.
review.description:
Maybe my review is a little different than the reviews you have read about UIUC.  You see, I was a student there from 1962 to 1966.  I graduated when dinosaurs roamed the quadrangle and women had to be in their dorms tucked in by 10:30 pm on weekdays and 1 am on weekends.

When I was at UIUC (and this is NOT a misprint), one semester's in-state tuition and fees were $135/semester.  It only cost about $1000-1200 per YEAR if you lived and ate in a university residence hall.

And I remember some of the mouth watering meals they served like SOS (no, not the scouring pads), Salisbury steak with gook on it, many variations of mystery meat, turkey tetrazzini, and so on.

Four semesters of ROTC and Physical Education were mandatory, wasting six hours' perfectly good time every week - a time better spent sleeping, fooling around, drinking beer, or pursuing other intellectual interests.

The university was less selective in admissions at that time.  It would take almost all high school graduates who scored in the top half of their classes, and would take a few from the third quartile too.  Of course, then as now, they hired semi-literates to stock the football and basketball teams. The Daily Illini's Roger Ebert frequently wrote sarcastic articles about Dick Butkus, painting him as somebody who had no business taking up space there.

In reality, the students who were not in about the top quartile of their high school teams usually left the university by the end of their first year - so UIUC did graduate top-ranked students as they do today.  Indeed I had a roommate who flunked out in his senior year.

I will tell you that UIUC had exceedingly high standards, and I did receive a rigorous and challenging education, which qualified me for admission to another Big Ten university's graduate school - and a subsequent career in engineering and eventually middle management in marketing.  Yes, marketing.

Things do not change over time.  Freshmen got drunk at Kam's and puked all over the sidewalk.  Self-styled activists would try to save the world from all of its injustices - especially if a TV camera were focused on them, guys belched and farted, the passenger trains to/from Chicago were late, and a major objective of almost all students was to get laid.

All kidding aside, I am very proud of my experience and education at the U of I; and I will always be fond and grateful for my four years there.

review.author: Dan W.
review.description: The school is a excellent institution.\n\n They get one of the best engineering programs in the world. Would send my children here without thinking twice.

review.author: Samantha S.
review.description:
The University of Illinois was a wonderful place years ago when the tuition was low and it was all many of us could afford.
Unfortunately they did not maintain high standards.  Now the great professors are retiring.  The last ten years have been a nightmare of mismanagement.
Perhaps the University will be turned around by the new President.
But for now, there are many great universities to attend in the US.  Some neighboring states offer in state tuition to Illinois residents.  
If you want to party hardy, Illinois is the place to go.  If you want a good education that leads to professional success, many of the programs should be avoided.  Steer clear of the College of Media entirely.  Some programs are excellent:  engineering, Library Science, and others which can be researched.  But some should be avoided completely.

review.author: Xander S.
review.description:
As an electrical engineering graduate, I've been in full agreement with the reviews; our program, and engineering college as a whole is stellar. The professors are amazing, student body motivated, and the programs are very well funded.

But of course, nothing's perfect, and I have a few qualms with the engineering programs (elitist to an annoying degree), the overall university administration (some corruption, some nepotism, too much red tape!), parts of the student body (way too segregated, by class, race, interest group), but as a whole, it was a very fulfilling experience, and I'm glad for what it taught me. Perhaps more importantly, it did prepare me for the world that came after.

It's a great school; there might not be too much to do around town, but I've found that it brings people closer together, and I've never complained about that. I miss U of I, and the people I loved a great deal, and will continue to rep it's name out in Seattle!

review.author: Kayla V.
review.description: Pros: Great community, good eats, beautiful campus, great transportation, good financial aid system. \n\nCons: Academically poor, disappointing faculty in the MSW and MEng programs, LOTS of partying that gets out of hand and dangerous, uncaring about the student, racially charged environment.

review.author: Teej T.
review.description:
For my 600th review, it seemed appropriate to write about the place that brought me to the scenic wonderland of the Midwest, The University of Illinois here in delightful Urbana-Champaign.

For a Southern California pseudo-hipster and person of color raised in Los Angeles and educated in San Diego, the U of I is a bit of a disorienting shock.  It's gigantic, yet full of personality and character.  It's also on some levels every stock stereotype about the 'college experience', from the pretentious architecture (that screams "we look like an East Coast college!!!  Bricks!!  Yay!!!") to the terrifying/amazing/astounding/bizarrely huge percentage of students involved in a Greek life that resembles in almost creepy detail the stereotypical movie depictions of said groups, to the absolute obsession Illini sports engenders.

I love a lot of it, with the fantastic resources, first class scholarship and immense potential.  I turned down Stanford and a few other 'name' schools as I was amazed and remain constantly impressed by their history doctoral program, and I'm thankful to be here for the education.  However, the location is a bit remote (although sometimes corn can be charming, I swear!), and there are some considerable issues here at U of I that have to be mentioned.

While the U of I is definitely a brilliant academic institution and a great place for meaningful exchanges of ideas, diversity is weak here, and cultural understanding/communication is particularly weak.  The issues surrounding the infamous mascot linger on years after its supposed resolution, and to be a person of color in central Illinois is occasionally a difficult and daunting prospect indeed.  I've been called the 'n' word already, and it's a hard place to process when there are screaming groups of students that have been known to have 'tacos and tequila' parties and still openly ask for the return of a racial caricature as a mascot.  It's daunting, but not insurmountable.

Most of the students I've met here are friendly, engaging, and generally cheerful.  They mean well, although it is *hard* to sometimes deal with racism either explicit or less intentional, honestly, and incidences like this year's vandalism of the Native American art exhibit outside the culture houses are emblematic of that.

That said, the school's trying.  The people of color are vibrant that are here, there is a good community, and it's growing.  I'm thankful for that.  There's a strong organizing tradition here.  People *care* about things, and it's nice to see.

A year after accepting their decision to come here, I don't regret it one bit, but Illinois is far from perfect or ideal.  It's a fantastic and wonderfully intellectually rigorous place, but it's also a daily challenge, particularly for us people of color who often have to fight to make our own spaces.  But I love it enough here to keep trying, and I certainly won't stop any time soon.

Besides, I've got at least another four years to go 'til I get to be Dr. Teej.

review.author: Jeff B.
review.description:
Ignore the haters.

I loved this school from the minute I stepped onto the campus for my college visit. It was the only college I applied to, and I miss my undergrad years there immensely. It was a time of great growth and experience, and it really is what you make of it. If you apply yourself and make an effort to reach out, have new experiences, and make new friends, you're going to have a great time. 

Join a student organization, or better yet, start one. Find some ethnic cuisine you've never tried before. Skip the campus bars every now and then and try out downtown Champaign. Pull an all-nighter in the UGL. Go to your professor's office hours for a change. Pick up some B movies at That's Rentertainment. Play intramural sports. Get a job at a dorm dining hall and make lifelong friends. Watch some kids play Dance Dance Revolution extremely well in the Illini Union. Read a book of poems on the Quad. 

I'm not a frat bro. Nothing like one. And, though Illinois has more than its fair share of them, you definitely don't have to go Greek to love UIUC.

review.author: Rose C.
review.description:
I'm sure that this will be taken down very soon by Yelp but I figure it doesn't hurt to say this one more time for those folks defending this school and their actions: Black Lives Matter does NOT indicate that ONLY Black Lives Matter. That's not what the movement is about. It is about shedding light on the racial and systemic injustices that our black communities and neighbors endure on a daily basis - it is meant to teach, to educate, to reform. If you are threatened or worried about something on a t-shirt, you're likely someone who needs to step back to reevaluate yourself and your privileges. Why are you upset that we care about our BIPOC and POC communities? Isn't that allowed? Should it be celebrated, especially with our youth?

I would love, love, love a daycare and childcare center that taught children at a young age to practice love, empathy, and learning. Too bad this place isn't it! I'm seeing so many reviews say things like how this childcare center is correct in how they acted because they should just let kids be kids. What? Why? You want to put blinders over your kids eyes to what is going on in the world? That's exactly how you create ignorant people. We should be teaching our children about what's going on - not hiding them from it. BLM isn't political. It's humanity. 

This school deserves its one star and I hope that nobody sends their kids here. It seems they lack basic values of Christianity. What if I wore a shirt that said "Breast Cancer Sucks." Is that a political view too? Does it mean that breast cancer is the only cancer that matters? What if it means something very personal to the child wearing it? would this center send the kid home for caring about a cause? Ridiculous.

review.author: Kay T.
review.description: How are you threatened by a shirt with words? You call yourself a Christian School, welcoming all but your actions state otherwise? I also noticed on your FACEBOOK page of your end of the year pictures (June) only pictures of Caucasian children, so your prejudice was showing some time ago.\nSHAME ON YOU, INCLUSION, LOVE FOR ALL GODS CHILDREN IS WHAT YOU SHOULD BE TEACHING, NOT HATE & SEGREGATION!

review.author: Tashi P.
review.description:
All lives can't matter until black lives matter.

For anyone who still doesn't understand this concept:

https://www.vox.com/2016/7/11/12136140/black-all-lives-matter

review.author: Thomas M.
review.description: Probably ok if your child is brought up in a hypocritical, racist household. For anyone not comfortable with that setting, it's probably best that you look elsewhere. If faith-based education is important to you, seek out institutions that actually operate within and strive for the principles within their professed belief system instead of ones that act in direct defiance of it. Pathetic.

review.author: Edi D.
review.description: Shame on you for demonizing a momma trying to teach her child the importance of advocating for civil rights. Too bad if it makes you uncomfortable: what does that say about you?? I would not trust this preschool to protect and honor the unique attributes of any child.

review.author: Shelia K.
review.description: Really upset with the narrative that Black Lives Matter being a "political movement" A person and the color of their skin and the way they are treated is not a politic to be discussed. I hope this place has learned to be better, but knowing the history of Arkansas, I don't have a lot of faith.

review.author: yazmine p.
review.description: I would never allow my kids to attend a school who believes that wearing a Black Lives matter shirt condemns racisms. if you are afraid about other parents being upset their kids will ask about why black lives matter, than the parents really need to get a reality check and read the bible again. don't be a hypocrite. I would not enroll your children in this racist's school.

review.author: Crystal H.
review.description: DON'T SEND YOUR CHILD HERE!!! This place is corrupted and silences children's voices. They banned a six-year-old girl from wearing a Black Lives Matter shirt! The officials and staff at this school won't let your your kids practice their first amendment right of free speech. They refuse to accept what is going on in the world right now with the Black Lives Matter Movement and instead choose to oppress those kids who stand for something as it doesn't align with their values. This is supposed to be a place of learning and acceptance yet THIS PLACE IS EVIL AND CORRUPT. You'd be better off at another facility that actually allows children to express themselves freely.

review.author: Lynda F.
review.description: Apparently HIS KIDS doesn't include fine Black children...bad place that humiliates children and has bias against expressive tasteful clothing. Shame on you!

review.author: Myah K.
review.description: My child expressed how unsafe she felt here, the staff is horrible.

review.author: Karen H.
review.description: How can you kick a child out of your facility for promoting what is true? Black Lives Matter. That is not up for debate. I hope that other parents take their children out of this "preschool" because it is obviously not being run be competent people. I fear for the safety of the children of color going there.

review.author: Tasha W.
review.description: If I could give a lower rating I would. You're what's wrong in this country. We have been denied and silenced for so long and you in your high horse are threatened by it, shame on you!

review.author: Louis W.
review.description: Shameful that you would remove a girl from school for exercising free speech on a T Shirt. Unless you want your kids to grow up and be racists do not send them here!

review.author: D. H.
review.description: Beware the "dress code." A 6-year-old was kicked out for wearing a BLM shirt. Black Lives Matter is not a political issue.

review.author: Lynn W.
review.description: Horrible racist staff. Thought they could traumatize a six year old child because she wore a shirt that celebrated the police not murdering black people. How they consider themselves a Christian facility is beyond me. I would be checking in unannounced several times a day to see what else these judgmental people are doing to these children.

review.author: Fishy L.
review.description: Any school that is going to kick out a kid over a shirt that had no offensive images or words is a school that doesn't know how to properly handle situations like this and will definitely fail to handle other serious situations.

review.author: Tommy P.
review.description:
Let me start off by saying that I feel like I'm the kinda person who lingers between Andy Dwyer and Ron Swanson. So before you take this too seriously, let me remind you that this is a Yelp review. That being said, I'd love to come out of retirement for this review and talk about something that I've cared so deeply about ever since I joined Greek Life, in the time before twitter. Lame ik.. 

First, I highly recommend going Greek no matter what your age is. But before you do, know that there is a standard you must meet. The school will tell you that you need a minimum GPA of 2.5 in college or in High School (if you're an incoming freshman). But lets be real, if you're coming out of HS with a GPA between a 2.5 & 2.8 you need to seriously consider establishing a solid GPA for a semester or two before you join. Now for the part they won't talk about during recruitment.. You need to be a person of solid character and moral judgment. In life you're going to be put in awkward situations that you're not always going to have a good answer for. But you don't have to be a rocket scientist to know the difference between good and bad. You'll learn proper etiquette later and will mold in to the person you were meant to be as you get older. That's life. 

Now who doesn't love sorority rush?? I'll be quick and to the point. As a whole, sororities at ATU need to use more glitter and the Campus Rush video needs a serious overhaul. The music in the video is comparable to Nickelback playing at a Chuck E Cheese venue. (Cringe) Now I understand the school wants to come off as a safe and conservative place for students. But seriously? Ew. My experience with sororities has been excellent. Something about southern ladies helping the community and being leaders on campus is a thing of beauty. (To my knowledge the Panhellenic Council is a secret society of robe wearers who all carry gavels) Idk I've never been to one of their meetings, it's just what I've heard.

For the men in Greek Life, I'll make this super short and hopefully you'll get something out of it:
You're born male, You grow in to a man, and you choose to be a gentleman. You can be cool and interact with everyone on campus without having to act insecure. Do that and you're college experience will be so much more bearable.
 
Now for the PRO'S: 1 Speaking from experience, Greek Life gives you a platform to meet and get out in front of new people.  2 You'll make a ton of new friends and make memories that will last a lifetime. Who knew this was possible in Russellville? 3 Opportunities to get involved are endless. You can literally do incredible things to help the community. 4 Mixers!! Need I say more? 5 Greek Week. This is hard to explain unless you've been through it.

And finally: The CON'S : 1 The Link 2 Mandatory meetings and events 3 No Greek housing. Seriously Tech needs to get on this. It's kind of embarrassing and hard to justify all of the improvements on campus while not have Greek housing. 4 Student Services can be your best friend or worst nightmare. Elect intelligent and hard working leaders!! 5 Fines 6 Living in Russellville. 

I could go on all day. Seriously. (Willing to change my review to 5 stars pending I get my photo hung up and placed in Doc Bryan). @RiffRaffPayne

review.author: Nancy R.
review.description: Wow , I've never been to elementary school where children were so polite and respectful, great job to their parents and educators.

review.author: Daniel S.
review.description: If you are looking for the best possible education for your elementary age children look no further! Immaculate Conception School has provided the best possible academic and spiritual based education for generations of our family. A presidential blue ribbon school award winner and leader in the community of private schools in the Arkansas River Valley IC a school will not disappoint you or your children.

name: The Bridge Birth and Family Services

review.author: Lauren H.
review.description: Lanette is an amazing birth coach and midwife. She is thorough, educated, and respectful. I appreciated being educated and then given space to make my own informed decision. I'm so thankful for her and others on my birth team. I can't imagine what this process would have been like with out her!

review.author: Eileen B.
review.description: Lynette was a grounding force and an amazing support during the birth of my second child. I don't even have words for the level of gratitude I feel. I would recommend that everyone has the same supportive care through pregnancy and birth that my family and I were fortunate to experience.

review.author: e j.
review.description: Lynette was our Bradley birth instructor and, then, our Doula. She KNOWS HER STUFF. As a pharmacist, I understand the importance of evidence-based practice, and everything Lynette taught us and advocated was based on the most current guidelines and her years of experience. She helped to support both me and my husband as we successfully reached our goal of having a medication-free birth. My pregnancy was healthy and so was our baby, thanks in large part to Lynette educating us on the healthiest foods and exercises. She was a blessing to us and I highly recommend her services.

review.author: Ellen W.
review.description: Lynette was an incredibly positive force in our birth story. We met her through her Bradley Method course, where we spent 12 weeks together. She taught such an empowering curriculum that made me feel so confident in the choices I had made for my birth plan. I truly feel the education she gave us allowed me to advocate for the birth I wanted. She went above and beyond to provide information as different issues came up in my pregnancy, allowing me to make truly informed decisions that I was totally comfortable with.  At a week past my due date, the hospital forced me to schedule an induction and Lynette was the first person I contacted (after a good cry). She helped me to consider all my options and at the end of the day, helped me transfer care to a birth center that would honor my choice to wait as long as was medically safe for baby to come. She attended my birth as a student midwife, and was a strong steady presence through the transition and pushing phases of my labor.  She is calm and encouraging during birth and I felt safe and powerful as I brought my son into the world. I tell people giving birth is the most empowering thing I've ever done, and Lynette was a big part of making that my reality. I'm so thankful for her.

review.author: Shaina B.
review.description: I had the great pleasure of working with Lynette on multiple occasions. I first met her as I was photographing a birth and she was the Doula. Then, I was blessed to have her as a midwife on my team while pregnant with my third baby and she attended that birth and took care of my daughter after her delivery. She is so calm, loving, and supportive. I would recommend her to anyone who is looking to have a great birth experience. She is very knowledgeable and makes you feel safe and in good hands. I consider her part of our family now!

name: Top Notch Home Inspection & Home Inspector School

review.author: Mark M.
review.description:
yesterday I had my home here in Olympia inspected by Robbie of Top Notch. Being a military vet, the term top notch meant you were the best of the best, so to speak. This company is truly the best and I am very happy with the high level of both expertise and professionalism I was given.
Inspector Smith was courteous and knowledgeable of my specific home including having researched county records, when my house was built and with what materials, etc. Very impressive.

Prices were very reasonable-also the military appreciation and the 10%off really helps a middle class vets living on a tight budget.                                                                                                    

Top Notch is licensed, insured and bonded LLC (I did my homework too:) and performed a detailed complete inspection of my home to include a final report with pictures to support the narrative-very pleased and thanks again Top Notch for saving me money while getting the job done right.                                                                                                         

Top Notch Inspection company is excellent in all regards and defines the meaning of TOP NOTCH...I would definitely hire Top Notch Inspection Company again and highly recommend this honest company to other businesses or homeowners in the Olympia-Thurston County areas...
Mark M.

review.author: Steve M.
review.description:
I've gone through many home inspections and would not pay $500 (or a nickel) for Top-Notch Home inspectors to do my home inspection.

You are basically paying the owner Robbie to spend your money training his employees or students (rather than spending time with the homeowner).  

I was at work and depended on him to give an accurate assessment of the inspection to my wife. BAD IDEA.  I would not leave my wife with him during an inspection again.  

I  wouldn't mind him training his students but he didn't even go over major items found during the inspection.  At the inspection he said only little minor items found so we waived our inspection contingency based on what HE said but now is blaming us.

Not until I looked in detail at the report did I discover major items that should have been brought up as red flags. For example, one of his documents noted "acceptable water pressure" to be between 40 to 90 psi. The reading he took a pic of for our house was barely 30psi. Also noted was water flow was very low and "indications of a DEFECT in the water supply". Had I not analyzed the report, we would have never known. 

We were left scrambling to figure out what to do since we waived our inspection and had no recourse with the seller for the defects before buying the house! We wasted our time and our realtor's time to get resolved.  

When confronted, Robbie only gave us excuses and now is blaming us for the poor inspection. We waived our inspection contingency because of what HE told us, let's get that clear.  

Contrary to what Robbie says, my concern for low water pressure and water flow is NOT a personal preference or an opinion. It was way below the standard MINIMUM ACCEPTABLE industry range (even says that in his own documents). When confronted, he even said that was way too low for his home and had to fix. Now he says it's beyond his legal requirement as a home inspector to tell me.  

"indications of a defect in the water system"  his company's words in the inspection report. 

Why would you not mention during or after the inspection and leave it to homeowner to find out. Because they were wrapping up to go to their next inspection is what he told me the reason he said only minor issues found and it's up to us to let them know we wanted them to spend more time with us to cover the issues. How are we supposed to know?

review.author: Steve G.
review.description:
Top Notch Home Inspection inspected my home in Toledo, WA, on Sept 2, 2022 and extensively damaged my garage door, by not following manufacturers guidelines for testing the safety reverse function.  Worse, Top Notch has not taken responsibility for the damage they caused.  
In testing the reverse function of the opener, the Top Notch Inspector lowered the door and, while the door was coming down, "tested" the reverse function by attempting to stop the door when it reached his waist level (the inspector is a large, strong man) from descending further by using what appeared to be all of his arm, shoulder and body strength.  He applied considerable force to stop the movement of the metal panel door.  I directly observed he even attempted to reverse the downward momentum of the door's direction by pulling/pushing up on the door, against its downward motion.  The door temporarily halted, grinded and then, after "maximum" force was applied and then released, grinded downward.

The very next time I opened the door, it rose approximately one third of the way, then it shook, ground, vibrated violently, twisting in the roller frame, the garage door window shattered, spewing glass all over the garage and stopped.  The top frame, where the opener operator arm attaches to door, had buckled, causing the warping/torquing of door in the frame, and causing the window glass to break.   Previous to Top Notch's "test," the door operated flawlessly.
  
Garage Door Opener Manufacturer guidance for testing the reverse function is explicit and clear:  you place a 2x4" board flat on the ground and allow the door to descend, strike the board and reverse.  You do not "yard" on the door as it is descending.  Manufacturers adamantly warn against this maneuver, saying it is both dangerous and will often result in over-torquing metal panel doors, resulting in extensive damage.
  
I spent considerable time cleaning up the mess from the breakage, making temporary repairs to the garage door, replacing the glass, obtaining estimates and filing extensive paperwork with Top Notch's Insurance Company, where my claim has now idled five weeks with no action taken.  This insurance diversion tactic is a way some unscrupulous companies use to get the claim out of mind and out of sight, where the insurance company will ultimately find a way to deny it.  Meanwhile, the homeowner has to absorb the costs of thousands of dollars of damage to his/her property caused by, in this case, inspector negligence.
   
I deeply regret allowing Top Notch into my home and will never do so again.  Addressing the damage thus far has cost me weeks of my life, with more to come.  It's ironic that Top Notch is also a Home Inspection School, teaching new inspectors the "correct" way to inspect homes.  Mistakes are sometimes made, but reputable companies will assume responsibility for them and indemnify those affected.  Not this company.   It has been nothing but a protracted stonewalling and avoidance maneuver with refusal to correct a glaring error.  Realtors that commission home inspections may also share in liability for inspector negligence that leads to substantial, unresolved damage.

review.author: Christina E.
review.description: Robbie and his assistant were wonderful to work with. I needed an assessment of my dads home to know whether to repair or not. They were very efficient and professional. They explained their findings and provided clear insight. Would highly recommend!

review.author: Lindsey S.
review.description: Robbie is a thorough inspector and is able to explain things in a way that is easy to understand. I wouldn't buy a house again without his professional opinion.
